"http://www.citynews.ca/2017/08/09/canadian-pastor-released-health-reasons-north-korea/", "body": "In this file image made from July 30, 2015, video, Canadian Hyeon Soo Lim speaks in Pyongyang, North Korea. THE CANADIAN PRESS/AP\n\nNorth Korea says it has released a Canadian pastor who has been serving a life sentence since 2015 for anti-state activities over health reasons.\n\nPyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency said on its website Wednesday that Hyeon Soo Lim was released on \"sick bail\" following a decision by the country's Central Court.\n\nThe news was announced after a delegation from the Canadian government went to Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nThe pastor went to North Korea on Jan. 31, 2015 for a humanitarian mission, one of more than 100 trips to the country since 1997, to support an orphanage, nursery and nursing home, his relatives and colleagues have said.\n\nThey were also worried about his health, saying he needs medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, told The Canadian Press on Tuesday.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe Canadian delegation is led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.\n\nThe last time a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old pastor was in late 2016.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\nWith files from The Associated Press", "time": "12:24:00"}

"Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/08/12/breaking-news/pastor-freed-from-north-korean-prison-arrives-back-in-canada/", "body": "James Lim, the son of Rev. Hyeon Soo Lim, spoke to the media at the Light Presbyterian Church, in Mississauga, Ontario, today.\n\nMISSISSAUGA, Ontario >> A Canadian pastor who was imprisoned for more than two years in North Korea arrived back home today.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim was serving a life sentence of hard labor in North Korea for alleged anti-state activities, but was released last week on what the North Korean government described as sick bail.\n\nHis son, James Lim, said it was surreal to see him again after living in fear over what might happen to him.\n\nJames Lim said his dad was extremely grateful to the Canadian government. He said his father was resting at home and looked forward to going to his church's Sunday service and meeting with the community after so long.\n\n\"Now more than ever, he's never felt more Canadian,\" the son said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau sent national security adviser Daniel Jean to North Korea to seek Lim's freedom.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 for allegedly trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt were coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim is pastor at the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.", "time": "02:06:00"}

"http://www.citynews.ca/2017/08/09/canadian-delegation-sent-north-korea-discuss-imprisoned-pastor/", "body": "In this file image made from July 30, 2015, video, Canadian Hyeon Soo Lim speaks in Pyongyang, North Korea. THE CANADIAN PRESS/AP\n\nA delegation from the Canadian government is in Pyongyang, North Korea, to discuss the case of imprisoned Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, the Prime Minister's Office confirmed Tuesday.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga was sentenced in December 2015 by a North Korean court to life in prison at hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nThe Canadian delegation - which is led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau - is in the North Korean capital as tensions continue to rise between the United States and the isolated nation, which announced Tuesday it developed the ability to fit a small nuclear warhead on top of a long-range missile.\n\nThe last time a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old pastor was in late 2016.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, said in an email.\n\n\"As this is an active case, we will not provide further comment at this time.\"\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\nLim's relatives and colleagues have said he travelled to North Korea on Jan. 31, 2015, as part of a regular humanitarian mission to the country where he supports a nursing home, a nursery and an orphanage. They said Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997 and that his trips were about helping people and were not political. They also have said he needs medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.", "time": "10:37:00"}

THE CANADIAN PRESS/AP\n\nSEOUL, Korea, Republic Of - North Korea says it has released a Canadian pastor who has been serving a life sentence since 2015 for anti-state activities over health reasons.\n\nPyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency said on its website Wednesday that Hyeon Soo Lim was released on \"sick bail\" following a decision by the country's Central Court.\n\nThe news was announced after a delegation from the Canadian government went to Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison at hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nThe Canadian delegation is led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.\n\nThe last time a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old pastor was in late 2016.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\nWith files from The Associated Press\n\nFollow us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter", "time": "11:38:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyeon_Soo_Lim", "label": {"eng": "Hyeon Soo Lim"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288147"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/canadian-delegation-north-korea-discuss-jailed-pastor-49107761", "body": "North Korea said Wednesday it released a Canadian pastor who has been serving a life sentence since 2015 for alleged anti-state activities over health reasons.\n\nPyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency said that Hyeon Soo Lim was released on \"sick bail\" following a decision by the country's Central Court. The agency didn't provide further details.\n\nThe office of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau earlier said that a delegation led by his national security adviser, Daniel Jean, arrived in Pyongyang on Tuesday to discuss Lim's imprisonment.\n\nLim, a South Korean-born Canadian citizen in his 60s, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 on charges of trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt had been coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after the death of U.S. college student Otto Warmbier shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nTrudeau's spokesman Cameron Ahmad said the government considered Lim's health of \"utmost importance\" but did not give more details about the delegation.\n\nLim pastored the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues. Lim met with the Swedish ambassador at least twice this year and met Canadian officials in December.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.", "time": "09:22:00"}

Korea to discuss imprisoned pastor", "body": "A delegation from the Canadian government is in Pyongyang, North Korea, to discuss the case of imprisoned Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, the Prime Minister's Office confirmed Tuesday.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., was sentenced in December 2015 by a North Korean court to life in prison at hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nThe Canadian delegation -- which is led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau -- is in the North Korean capital as tensions continue to rise between the United States and the isolated nation, which announced Tuesday it developed the ability to fit a small nuclear warhead on top of a long-range missile.\n\nThe last time a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old pastor was in late 2016.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, said in an email.\n\n\"As this is an active case, we will not provide further comment at this time.\"\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\nLim's relatives and colleagues have said he travelled to North Korea on Jan. 31, 2015, as part of a regular humanitarian mission to the country where he supports a nursing home, a nursery and an orphanage. They said Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997 and that his trips were about helping people and were not political. They also have said he needs medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.", "time": "08:11:00"}

which Canadian authorities have strongly denied.\n\nNorth Korea has released a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence there on humanitarian grounds, the country's official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday.\n\nThere was no obvious direct connection between the release and the standoff with the United States, but North Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington, and visits by high-profile Americans, with the detention and release of USA citizens.\n\nThe report did not elaborate further details of the visit, but it is speculated that the envoy is there to discuss the issue of Korean-Canadian pastor Lim Hyeon-soo who is now detained in North Korea.\n\nThe news was announced after a delegation from the Canadian government went to Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case.\n\nOn Tuesday, Canadian officials travelled to North Korea to discuss releasing the imprisoned pastor.\n\n\"A Canadian government delegation is now in Pyongyang to discuss Pastor Lim's case\", Trudeau's press secretary Cameron Ahmad said.\n\n'Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case, ' he said.\n\nLim was convicted and sentenced in 2015 on charges of trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping US and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nIt comes at a high of heightened tensions between North Korea and the West after US President Donald Trump reacted with fury to an intelligence report that suggested Pyongyang had the nuclear firepower to hit America.\n\nThe pastor was reportedly involved in projects linked to some associates of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un's purged uncle, Jang Song Thaek, who was executed in 2013 for treason.\n\nLast "http://www.macleans.ca/news/canadian-officials-in-north-korea-in-effort-to-free-prisoner/", "body": "In this file image made from July 30, 2015, video, Canadian Hyeon Soo Lim speaks in Pyongyang, North Korea. THE CANADIAN PRESS/AP\n\nA delegation from the Canadian government is in Pyongyang, North Korea, to discuss the case of imprisoned Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, the Prime Minister's Office confirmed Tuesday.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., was sentenced in December 2015 by a North Korean court to life in prison at hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nThe Canadian delegation -- which is led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau -- is in the North Korean capital as tensions continue to rise between the United States and the isolated nation, which announced Tuesday it developed the ability to fit a small nuclear warhead on top of a long-range missile.\n\nThe last time a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old pastor was in late 2016.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, said in an email.\n\n\"As this is an active case, we will not provide further comment at this time.\"\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\nLim's relatives and colleagues have said he travelled to North Korea on Jan. 31, 2015, as part of a regular humanitarian mission to the country where he supports a nursing home, a nursery and an orphanage. They said Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997 and that his trips were about helping people and were not political. They also have said he needs medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nMORE ABOUT NORTH KOREA:\n\nRelax, Donald Trump's threats about North Korea are meaningless United Nations imposes new sanctions on North Korea North Korea missiles are reaching higher and further than ever before Trump, Asian allies discuss response to 'menace' of North Korea Trump considering 'pretty severe things' in response to North Korea North Korea says it is ready to mass-produce medium-range missile U.S. sets up missile defence in South Korea U.S. tells North Korea: We don't want a fight, don't start one Follow us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter", "time": "11:05:00"}

South Korea -- North Korea said Wednesday it released a Canadian pastor who has been serving a life sentence since 2015 for alleged anti-state activities over health reasons.\n\nPyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency said that Hyeon Soo Lim was released on \"sick bail\" following a decision by the country's Central Court. The agency didn't provide further details.\n\nThe office of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau earlier said that a delegation led by his national security adviser, Daniel Jean, arrived in Pyongyang on Tuesday to discuss Lim's imprisonment.\n\nLim, a South Korean-born Canadian citizen in his 60s, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 on charges of trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt had been coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after the death of U.S. college student Otto Warmbier shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nTrudeau's spokesman Cameron Ahmad said the government considered Lim's health of \"utmost importance\" but did not give more details about the delegation.death of U.S. college student Otto Warmbier\n\nLim pastored the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues. Lim met with the Swedish ambassador at least twice this year and met Canadian officials in December.", "time": "14:47:00"}

"1288189"}], "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/north-korea-releases-jailed-canadian-pastor-amid-standoff-with-us-4789694/", "body": "By: Reuters | Seoul | Published:August 9, 2017 10:11 pm South Korea-born Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim stands during his trial at a North Korean court in this undated photo released by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) in Pyongyang December. (Source: Reuters) North Korea considering strike on Guam after Donald Trump warns of 'fire and fury'North Korea has produced nuclear warhead small enough to fit inside its missiles: reportUS pushes Asian nations on North Korea\n\nNorth Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nThere was no clear connection between the release of Hyeon Soo Lim and the heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang. Canadian officials said on Tuesday a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had gone to North Korea to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Strategically, North Korea perhaps hopes to engender some goodwill from Canada as tensions rise,\" said Charles Burton, a former Canadian diplomat in China. \"They hope that Canada presents some\n\nmoderating influence on the Trump administration.\n\n\"(But) I do not think it is directly connected to the tensions the US president has ratcheted up. North Korea is concerned he would die in prison.\" KCNA said Lim had been released on \"sick bail\" by the country's Central Court for humanitarian reasons.\n\nLim, accompanied by his wife and son, is expected to return to Canada on Thursday and will be hospitalized on arrival at his wife's request, a source familiar with the matter said.\n\n\"So far, it has been confirmed that government officials and a doctor are accompanying Reverend Lim,\" said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak\n\nto media.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months. Warmbier, sentenced last year to\n\n15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel, died in a Cincinnati hospital days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nCanadian Senator Yonah Martin, who advocated for Lim's release, said Lim was hospitalized during his imprisonment.\n\n\"They were sending medication but there was a question as to whether he was actually receiving it in the way he should,\" he said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office did not comment on Wednesday.\n\nNorth Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington and visits by high-profile Americans with the detention and release of US citizens.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The US State Department said last week it would ban U.S. nationals from travelling to the isolated country from September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump, unhappy with Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program, told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: North korea", "time": "16:59:00"}

"http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-12-CN-Canada-North-Korea-Detainee/id-3556279ebac74536ac9df6b104d4d938", "body": "MISSISSAUGA, Ontario (AP) -- A Canadian pastor who was imprisoned for more than two years in North Korea arrived back home Saturday.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim was serving a life sentence of hard labor in North Korea for alleged anti-state activities, but was released last week on what the North Korean government described as sick bail.\n\nHis son, James Lim, said it was surreal to see him again after living in fear over what might happen to him.\n\nJames Lim said his dad was extremely grateful to the Canadian government. He said his father was resting at home and looked forward to going to his church's Sunday service and meeting with the community after so long.\n\n\"Now more than ever, he's never felt more Canadian,\" the son said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau sent national security adviser Daniel Jean to North Korea to seek Lim's freedom.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 for allegedly trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt were coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim is pastor at the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.", "time": "00:10:00"}

Canadian pastor who has been serving a life sentence since 2015 for anti-state activities over health reasons.\n\nPyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency said on its website Wednesday that Hyeon Soo Lim was released on \"sick bail\" following a decision by the country's Central Court.\n\nThe news was announced after a delegation from the Canadian government went to Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison at hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about "http://www.ottawacitizen.com/news/canadian+delegation+north+korea+pastor/14107654/story.html", "body": "ShareAdjustCommentPrint\n\nA delegation from the Canadian government is in Pyongyang, North Korea, to discuss the case of imprisoned Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, the Prime Minister's Office confirmed Tuesday.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., was sentenced in December 2015 by a North Korean court to life in prison at hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nLim was charged with included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nThe Canadian delegation \u00e2\u0080\" which is led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau \u00e2\u0080\" is in the North Korean capital as tensions continue to rise between the United States and the isolated nation, which announced Tuesday it developed the ability to fit a small nuclear warhead on top of a long-range missile.\n\nThe last time a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old pastor was in late 2016.\n\n\"Pastor Lim\u00e2\u0080\u0099s health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Office, said in an email.\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cAs this is an active case, we will not provide further comment at this time.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\nLim's relatives and colleagues have said he travelled to North Korea on Jan. 31, 2015, as part of a regular humanitarian mission to the country where he supports a nursing home, a nursery and an orphanage. They said Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997 and that his trips were about helping people and were not political. They also have said he needs medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.", "time": "23:54:00"}

Canadian pastor released from a North Korean prison says he is on his way home.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau also confirmed that Hyeon Soo Lim has been released and will soon be reunited with his family. He had been serving a life sentence since 2015 for alleged anti-state activities.\n\nThe Korean Central News Agency on Wednesday reported the pastor had been released on what it called \"sick bail\" but no other details were given.\n\nFamily spokeswoman Lisa Pak said in a statement on Thursday \"there is a long way to go\" in terms of Lim's healing and said he needs privacy while receiving unspecified medical attention. Park said the family is relieved, grateful and anxious to see him.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 on charges of trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping US and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after US college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labour in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim pastored the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues. Lim met with the Swedish ambassador at least twice this year and met Canadian officials in December. Trudeau sent his national security adviser, Daniel Jean, to Pyongyang this week.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.", "time": "15:49:00"}

Ontario -- A Canadian pastor who was imprisoned for more than two years in North Korea arrived back home Saturday.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim was serving a life sentence of hard labor in North Korea for alleged anti-state activities, but was released last week on what the North Korean government described as sick bail.\n\nHis son, James Lim, said it was surreal to see him again after living in fear over what might happen to him.\n\nJames Lim said his dad was extremely grateful to the Canadian government. He said his father was resting at home and looked forward to going to his church's Sunday service and meeting with the community after so long.\n\n\"Now more than ever, he's never felt more Canadian,\" the son said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau sent national security adviser Daniel Jean to North Korea to seek Lim's freedom.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 for allegedly trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt were coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim is pastor at the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/nation/2017/08/12/pastor-freed-north-korea-arrives-canada/104539428/", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nMississauga, Ontario -- A Canadian pastor who was imprisoned for more than two years in North Korea arrived back home Saturday.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim was serving a life sentence of hard labor in North Korea for alleged anti-state activities, but was released last week on what the North Korean government described as sick bail.\n\nHis son, James Lim, said it was surreal to see him again after living in fear over what might happen to him.\n\nJames Lim said his dad was extremely grateful to the Canadian government. He said his father was resting at home and looked forward to going to his church's Sunday service and meeting with the community after so long.\n\n\"Now more than ever, he's never felt more Canadian,\" the son said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau sent national security adviser Daniel Jean to North Korea to seek Lim's freedom.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 for allegedly trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt were coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim is pastor at the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.talkmedianews.com/featured/2017/08/09/north-korea-frees-canadian-missionary-sick-bail/", "body": "WASHINGTON - North Korea released on humanitarian grounds a Canadian missionary who was serving a life sentence for \"trying to overthrow the regime,\" Pyongyang said on Wednesday.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, disappeared in North Korea in February 2015 and in December of that year was sentenced for \"subversive acts against Pyongyang.\" Canadian authorities strongly denied the charges. North Korean officials also said the pastor allegedly confessed to helping people escape from the country.\n\nLim, also known as Rim Hyon Su, was freed Wednesday after a Canadian delegation was sent to Pyongyang to discuss the his case. Canadian officials were apparently concerned about reports that the South Korean-born pastor had suffered a dramatic weight loss. In letters to his family, he complained of stomach pains and high blood pressure.\n\n\"Rim Hyon Su, a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail according to the decision of the Central Court of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea on August 9, 2017, from the humanitarian viewpoint,\" North Korea's official KCNA news agency said Wednesday.\n\nA Canadian government spokesman had confirmed on Tuesday that a delegation led by National Security Advisor Daniel Jean was in Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case. The spokesperson for Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Lim's health and well-being \"remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada.\"\n\nLim's family told local media they became very worried about his welfare since American college student Otto Warmbier died in June just days after being released from a North Korean prison.\n\nWhen Lim was arrested, Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States said he was one of the most influential Christian missionaries in North Korea.\n\nLim told CNN last year that he dug holes eight hours a day, six days a week in a labor camp.\n\nFamily spokesperson Lisa Pak said there was \"a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing.\" She thanked people for their prayers and support and asked that the world \"not forget the people of North Korea.\"\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in North Korea.\n\nLim's release coincides with a dramatic rise in tensions with North Korea as volatile leader Kim Jong-Un said he is considering plans to make \"an enveloping fire\" around the U.S. territory of Guam, which is home to a large American military base and about 163,000 people. Kim's threats follow those of President Donald Trump, who on Wednesday warned the North Korean leader that his country faces \"fire and fury like the world has never seen\" unless he ceases his threats against the U.S.", "time": "18:16:00"}

"http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/canadian-pastor-back-in-toronto-after-two-years-in-n.-korean-prison-video", "body": "TORONTO, Aug 13 -- A Canadian pastor who was imprisoned in North Korea for more than two years quietly returned to his home in a Toronto suburb on yesterday following a long journey on a private government jet via Japan.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, formerly the senior pastor at one of Canada's largest churches, had disappeared on a mission to North Korea in early 2015. He was sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015 on charges of attempting to overthrow the Pyongyang regime.\n\nNews of his release surfaced on Wednesday, when North Korea's KCNA news agency said Lim was being let go on humanitarian grounds, suggesting his health was poor.\n\nThe announcement came amid heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang, though authorities have not said there is any connection between his release and efforts to defuse the standoff over North Korea's nuclear programme.\n\nThe pastor's son James Lim said his dad was happy to be back home in Canada, stopping for coffee and a donut at Canada's popular Tim Horton's coffee chain on his way home from the airport.\n\nRev. Hyeon Soo Lim, who was imprisoned in North Korea for more than two years, is seen reuniting with his wife Keum Young Lim in this still image captured from a video in Toronto August 12, 2017. -- Reuters pic The family asked the public to respect their privacy, allowing him to rest for a day and catch up with family before appearing in public on Sunday to attend services at his church.\n\nJames Lim said his dad was in \"good health,\" but noted that the family planned to arrange for extended medical attention, including checkups.\n\n\"He is doing very well, considering everything he has gone through,\" he said.\n\nThe family thanked the Canadian government for helping secure his Lim's release. They declined to provide details on negotiations with the North Koreans.\n\n\"It's a delicate dance. There's a lot of complexity to it,\" James Lim said.\n\nHe added that getting the pastor home took on increased urgency in June, following the death of Otto Warmbier, an American student who died days after being released from a North Korean prison in a coma.\n\nThe Canadian government issued a statement saying it joined Lim's family and congregation in celebrating his homecoming.\n\n\"Canada has been actively engaged on Mr Lim's case at all levels, and we will continue to support him and his family now that he has returned,\" the statement said. -- Reuters", "time": "02:23:00"}

Canadian pastor released from a North Korean prison said Thursday he is now on his way home.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau also confirmed that Hyeon Soo Lim has been released and will soon be reunited with his family. He had been serving a life sentence since 2015 for alleged anti-state activities.\n\nThe Korean Central News Agency on Wednesday reported the pastor had been released on what it called \"sick bail,\" but no other details were given.\n\nFamily spokeswoman Lisa Pak said in a statement \"there is a long way to go\" in terms of Lim's healing and said he needs privacy while receiving unspecified medical attention. Park said the family is relieved, grateful and anxious to see him.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 on charges of trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt had been coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim pastored the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues. Lim met with the Swedish ambassador at least twice this year and met Canadian officials in December. Trudeau sent his national security adviser, Daniel Jean, to Pyongyang this week.\n\n\"The Government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels. In particular, I want to thank Sweden, our protecting power in North Korea, for assisting us,\" Trudeau said.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.", "time": "14:20:00"}

"body": "A Canadian pastor who was imprisoned in North Korea for more than two years quietly returned to his home in a Toronto suburb on Saturday following a long journey on a private government jet via Japan.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, formerly the senior pastor at one of Canada's largest churches, had disappeared on a mission to North Korea in early 2015. He was sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015 on charges of attempting to overthrow the Pyongyang regime.\n\nNews of his release surfaced on Wednesday, when North Korea's KCNA news agency said Lim was being let go on humanitarian grounds, suggesting his health was poor.\n\nThe announcement came amid heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang, though authorities have not said there is any connection between his release and efforts to defuse the standoff over North Korea's nuclear programme.\n\nThe pastor's son James Lim said his dad was happy to be back home in Canada, stopping for coffee and a donut at Canada's popular Tim Horton's coffee chain on his way home from the airport.\n\nThe family asked the public to respect their privacy, allowing him to rest for a day and catch up with family before appearing in public on Sunday to attend services at his church.\n\nFILE PHOTO - South Korea-born Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim stands during his trial at a North Korean court in this undated photo released by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) in Pyongyang, North Korea on December 16, 2015.KCNA/File Photo\n\nJames Lim said his dad was in \"good health,\" but noted that the family planned to arrange for extended medical attention, including checkups.\n\n\"He is doing very well, considering everything he has gone through,\" he said.\n\nThe family thanked the Canadian government for helping secure his Lim's release. They declined to provide details on negotiations with the North Koreans.\n\n\"It's a delicate dance. There's a lot of complexity to it,\" James Lim said.\n\nHe added that getting the pastor home took on increased urgency in June, following the death of Otto Warmbier, an American student who died days after being released from a North Korean prison in a coma.\n\nThe Canadian government issued a statement saying it joined Lim's family and congregation in celebrating his homecoming.\n\n\"Canada has been actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels, and we will continue to support him and his family now that he has returned,\" the statement said.", "time": "08:35:00"}

a Canadian pastor released from a North Korean prison said Thursday he is now on his way home.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau also confirmed that Hyeon Soo Lim has been released and will soon be reunited with his family. Park said the family is relieved, grateful and anxious to see him.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old South Korean-born Canadian citizen, was convicted and sentenced in 2015 on charges of trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system and helping U.S. and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens.\n\nSouth Korea, the U.S. and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt had been coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nLim's release came nearly two months after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier died shortly after he was released from North Korea in a coma. Warmbier had been sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016 after being accused of stealing a propaganda poster.\n\nLim pastored the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto. His supporters have said he was on a humanitarian mission to North Korea when he was detained.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues. Lim met with the Swedish ambassador at least twice this year and met Canadian officials in December. Trudeau sent his national security adviser, Daniel Jean, to Pyongyang this week.\n\n\"The Government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels. In particular, I want to thank Sweden, our protecting power in North Korea, for assisting us,\" Trudeau said.\n\nAt least three Americans and six South Koreans remain in custody in the North.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. expected to speak publicly on Sunday for the first time since his release from imprisonment in North Korea last week.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, is expected to attend Sunday's service at his church in Mississauga, Ont., near Toronto. He was reunited with his family in Ontario on Saturday after more than two years in detention in North Korea. The service is at Light Presbyterian Church, 6965 Professional Court, near Derry Road East and Goreway Drive.\n\nLim, who is a pastor at the church, is expected to speak at the end of the service.\n\nLim was arrested in North Korea in 2015 and sentenced to a life of hard labour in prison for alleged crimes against the state. He was released last week on what the North Korean government called \"sick bail.\"\n\nHis son, James Lim, told reporters in a news conference on Saturday that the family is thrilled that his father is now home.\n\nLim himself did not appear at the news conference, but he walked away from the plane unaided. His son said his father appeared to be in \"good health\" though the family plans to arrange for a complete checkup.\n\nWhen Lim was reunited with his family, he met his granddaughter, under a year old, for the first time. according to his son.\n\nIn a statement on Saturday, Global Affairs Canada said it celebrated his return to Canada.\n\n\"Canada has been actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels, and we will continue to support him and his family now that he has returned,\" the statement read.\n\nLim was freed after a six-member Canadian delegation, led by Daniel Jean, who serves as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security and intelligence adviser, travelled to Pyongyang. {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/north-korea-pastor-canadian/2017/08/10/id/806842/", "body": "North Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence on humanitarian grounds, the Canadian prime minister and North Korea's KCNA news agency said, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nA statement from Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office on Thursday said that Lim had been freed and \"will soon be reunited with his family and friends\".\n\nThere was no clear connection between the release of Hyeon Soo Lim and the heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang.\n\nThe pastor's case was taken up by a delegation led by the country's national security adviser that had gone to North Korea earlier in the week, it said. Sweden's embassy in Pyongyang, which represents several Western nations in the insular nation, had also helped, the statement said.\n\n\"Operational security considerations prevent us from discussing the matter further,\" it said.\n\nLim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Strategically, North Korea perhaps hopes to engender some goodwill from Canada as tensions rise,\" said Charles Burton, a former Canadian diplomat in China. \"They hope that Canada presents some moderating influence on the Trump administration.\n\n\"(But) I do not think it is directly connected to the tensions the U.S. president has ratcheted up. North Korea is concerned he would die in prison.\"\n\nNorth Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington and visits by high-profile Americans with the detention and release of U.S. citizens.\n\nKCNA said Lim had been released on \"sick bail\" by the country's Central Court for humanitarian reasons.\n\nLim is expected to return to Canada later on Thursday and will be hospitalised on arrival at his wife's request, a source familiar with the matter said. His family is arriving separately.\n\n\"So far, it has been confirmed that government officials and a doctor are accompanying Reverend Lim,\" said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorised to speak to media.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months. Warmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel, died in a Cincinnati hospital days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nCanadian Senator Yonah Martin, who advocated for Lim's release, said Lim was hospitalised during his imprisonment.\n\n\"They were sending medication but there was a question as to whether he was actually receiving it in the way he should.\"\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The U.S. State Department said last week it would ban U.S. nationals from travelling to the isolated country from September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the U.S. Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump, unhappy with Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program, told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury.\"", "time": "11:10:00"}

"http://english.astroawani.com/world-news/amid-standoff-u-s-north-korea-releases-jailed-canadian-pastor-151939", "body": "SEOUL/TORONTO: North Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nThere was no clear connection between the release of Hyeon Soo Lim and the heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang. Canadian officials said on Tuesday a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had travelled to North Korea to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime. KCNA said Lim had been released on \"sick bail\" by the country's Central Court for humanitarian reasons.\n\nLim, accompanied by his wife and son, is expected to return to Canada on Thursday and will be hospitalized on arrival at his wife's request, a source familiar with the matter said.\n\n\"So far, it has been confirmed that government officials and a doctor are accompanying Reverend Lim,\" said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak to media.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months. Warmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel, died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nNorth Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington and visits by high-profile Americans with the detention and release of U.S. citizens.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The U.S. State Department said last week it would ban U.S. nationals from travelling to the isolated country, beginning in September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the U.S. Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump, unhappy with Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program, told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury.\"", "time": "21:03:00"}

the decision of the Central Court of the North.\n\nLim, a Korean-Canadian pastor, has been held in captivity in the North since he entered the country via China on a humanitarian mission in January 2015.\n\nIn December, the North's highest court sentenced Lim to life in prison with hard labor, citing his \"subversive plots\" against the North's regime.\n\nHis release came one day after a special envoy of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arrived in the North.\n\nDaniel Jean, national security advisor to the prime minister of Canada, and his party arrived in Pyongyang, the KCNA reported on Tuesday.\n\nThe visit drew speculation that the envoy was to persuade the North to release the detained pastor.\n\nLim's family has been urging the Canadian government to step up efforts to release him after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier was released in a coma from North Korea in June following a 17-month detention and died days after a medical evacuation.\n\nLim has visited the country more than 100 times for humanitarian activities since 1997.\n\nSouth Korea on Thursday welcomed North Korea's release of the pastor, urging the North to free the South Korean citizens still held in captivity.\n\n\"Our government welcomes the release of pastor Lim Hyeon-soo, who had been detained in North Korea,\" Cho June-hyuck, spokesman at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said in a press briefing. The spokesman said Canada has been in close communication with South Korea on Lim's captivity as it is a like-minded country that supports South Korea's policy direction on the North.\n\nCurrently, six South Koreans, including three Christian missionaries and three Americans, are detained in the North.\n\nYonhap", "time": "11:58:00"}

heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang. Hyeon Soo Lim and the heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang. Canadian officials said on Tuesday a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had gone to North Korea to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Strategically, North Korea perhaps hopes to engender some goodwill from Canada as tensions rise,\" said Charles Burton, a former Canadian diplomat in China. \"They hope that Canada presents some moderating influence on the Trump administration.\n\nRelated articles\n\n\"(But) I do not think it is directly connected to the tensions the U.S. president has ratcheted up. "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4774750/index.html", "body": "Photo taken by North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency on December 16, 2015 shows Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim in court\n\nA Canadian pastor serving a life sentence with hard labour in North Korea was released Wednesday on medical parole as a humanitarian gesture, the official KCNA news agency said.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 61, was freed on \"sick bail\", the agency announced after a Canadian government delegation arrived in Pyongyang to discuss the case.\n\nA court ordered Lim's release \"from the humanitarian viewpoint\", it said in a brief two-paragraph report.\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation which Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nA Canadian delegation including national security adviser Daniel Jean visited Pyongyang this week to discuss the case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, in Ottawa before the release.\n\nLim's family told local media they had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington worsen sharply. The North said earlier Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after US President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile programme.\n\nAt the time of Lim's arrest, other members of the close-knit circle of ethnic Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States called him one of the most influential Christian missionaries operating in North Korea.\n\nHe had visited the country dozens of times, working with orphanages and nursing homes.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim Jong-Un.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\nLim told CNN last year that he spent his days in prison digging holes. \"I wasn't originally a labourer so the labour was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPyongyang views foreign missionaries with deep suspicion, though it allows some to undertake humanitarian work.\n\nA number of Christian missionaries -- mostly ethnic Koreans who are US citizens -- have been arrested in the past, with some of them only allowed to return home after intervention by high-profile US political figures.", "time": "12:14:00"}

"http://www.trtworld.com/asia/north-korea-releases-canadian-pastor-on-sick-bail-418489", "body": "North Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nThere was no clear connection between the release of Hyeon Soo Lim and the heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang. Canadian officials said on Tuesday a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had gone to North Korea to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Strategically, North Korea perhaps hopes to engender some goodwill from Canada as tensions rise,\" said Charles Burton, a former Canadian diplomat in China. \"They hope that Canada presents some moderating influence on the Trump administration.\n\n\"(But) I do not think it is directly connected to the tensions the US president has ratcheted up. North Korea is concerned he would die in prison.\"\n\nKCNA said Lim had been released on \"sick bail\" by the country's Central Court for humanitarian reasons.\n\nLim, accompanied by his wife and son, is expected to return to Canada on Thursday and will be hospitalised on arrival at his wife's request, a source familiar with the matter said.\n\n\"So far, it has been confirmed that government officials and a doctor are accompanying Reverend Lim,\" said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorised to speak to media.\n\nMore concerned\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months. Warmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel, died in a Cincinnati hospital days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nCanadian Senator Yonah Martin, who advocated for Lim's release, said Lim was hospitalised during his imprisonment.\n\n\"They were sending medication but there was a question as to whether he was actually receiving it in the way he should,\" he said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office did not comment on Wednesday.\n\nNorth Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington and visits by high-profile Americans with the detention and release of US citizens.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The US State Department said last week it would ban US nationals from travelling to the isolated country from September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump, unhappy with Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program, told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury.\"", "time": "15:35:00"}

for humanitarian reasons amid escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula stemming from the North's continued provocations.\n\nThe Korea Central News Agency, the communist state's official media outlet, reported that Hyeon Soo Lim, a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail in line with the decision of the Central Court of the North.\n\nLim, a Korean-Canadian pastor, has been held in captivity in the North since he entered the country via China on a humanitarian mission in January 2015.\n\nIn December, the North's highest court sentenced Lim to life in prison with hard labor, citing his \"subversive plots\" against the North's regime.\n\nHis release came one day after a special envoy of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arrived in the North.\n\nDaniel Jean, national security adviser to the prime minister of Canada, and his party arrived in Pyongyang, the KCNA reported Tuesday.\n\nThe visit drew speculation that the envoy was to persuade the North to release the detained pastor.\n\nLim's family has been urging the Canadian government to step up efforts to release him after U.S. college student Otto Warmbier was released in a coma from North Korea in June anti-state activities, due to health reasons.\n\nBut there were no details about when or how Hyeon Soo Lim might return to Canada.\n\nPyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency said on its website Wednesday that Lim was released on \"sick bail\" following a decision by the country's Central Court.\n\nThe news was announced after a delegation from the Canadian government went to Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, a 62-year-old pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church of Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nJohn Bae, administrative pastor at the Mississauga church, said he learned of the release early Wednesday, but had no other details.\n\n\"We don't know when Rev. Lim's going to get to Toronto. I'm in my office waiting for a call from somewhere, confirming that he's here,\" Bae said with a laugh. \"I haven't heard anything yet.\"\n\nBae said he got word of Lim's release in a text from Jason Noh, the church's senior pastor, who happened to be in South Korea, one destination on a trip to Asia. Noh planned to rush back to Canada, Bae said.\n\nThere was little comment from Canadian officials.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office.\n\nLim went to North Korea on Jan. 31, 2015, for a humanitarian mission, one of more than 100 trips to the country since 1997, to support an orphanage, nursery and nursing home, his relatives and colleagues have said.\n\nHe was charged with harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans and helping American and South Korean authorities lure and abduct North Korean citizens, along with aiding their programs to assist defectors from the North.\n\nAssociates were worried about Lim's health, saying he needs medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe Canadian delegation to North Korea was led by Daniel Jean, national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. The last time a Canadian delegation travelled to Pyongyang to discuss the pastor's release was in late 2016.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.", "time": "17:37:00"}

Canadian government delegation is in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang to discuss the case of imprisoned Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, the Prime Minister's Office confirmed Tuesday.\n\nThe delegation is reportedly led by Daniel Jean, national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.\n\nIt's the second time in about nine months that a Canadian envoy has been sent to Pyongyang to discuss the release of the 62-year-old senior pastor of the Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga. Lim is reportedly in failing health and has lost upwards of 60 pounds.\n\nThe pastor, who has made more than 110 humanitarian missions to North Korea on behalf of his church, has been in detention since January 2015. He went missing during a routine visit in a northern region where the Canadian was a familiar face. Local officials had granted him a frequent access visa.\n\nWeeks after his disappearance, North Korean authorities confirmed they'd arrested Lim, purportedly for scheming to overthrow Kim Jong Un's authoritarian regime. The pastor was sentenced to life in a hard labour camp in late 2015.\n\nRead more:\n\nTrump says North Korea will be met with 'fire and the fury like the world has never seen' if it doesn't stop threatening the U.S.", "time": "22:38:00"}

{"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/north-korea-releases-imprisoned-canadian-pastor-kcna-104802847.html", "body": "By Soyoung Kim and Hyungwon Kang\n\nSEOUL/TORONTO (Reuters) - North Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury.\"\n\nThere was no clear connection between the release of Hyeon Soo Lim and the heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang. Canadian officials said on Tuesday a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had gone to North Korea to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Strategically, North Korea perhaps hopes to engender some goodwill from Canada as tensions rise,\" said Charles Burton, a former Canadian diplomat in China. \"They hope that Canada presents some moderating influence on the Trump administration.\n\n\"(But) I do not think it is directly connected to the tensions the U.S. president has ratcheted up. North Korea is concerned he would die in prison.\"\n\nKCNA said Lim had been released on \"sick bail\" by the country's Central Court for humanitarian reasons.\n\nLim, accompanied by his wife and son, is expected to return to Canada on Thursday and will be hospitalized on arrival at his wife's request, a source familiar with the matter said.\n\n\"So far, it has been confirmed that government officials and a doctor are accompanying Reverend Lim,\" said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak to media.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months. Warmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labor for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel, died in a Cincinnati hospital days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nCanadian Senator Yonah Martin, who advocated for Lim's release, said Lim was hospitalized during his imprisonment.\n\n\"They were sending medication but there was a question as to whether he was actually receiving it in the way he should,\" he said.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office did not comment on Wednesday.\n\nNorth Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington and visits by high-profile Americans with the detention and release of U.S. citizens.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The U.S. State Department said last week it would ban U.S. nationals from traveling to the isolated country from September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labor camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the U.S. Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump, unhappy with Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program, told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury.\"\n\n(Additional reporting by Leah Schnurr in Ottawa, Ben Blanchard in Beijing and Chris Arsenault in Toronto; Editing by Bill Trott and James Dalgleish)", "time": "01:37:00"}

"url": "http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/north-korea-releases-canadian-pastor-held-since-2015-state-news-agency-1.3538255", "body": "After languishing for more than two years in a North Korean prison, a Canadian pastor was released Wednesday, according to the country's state news agency.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., had travelled to North Korea more than a hundred times, leading humanitarian programs and even opening an orphanage. But during his last trip in 2015, he was detained and charged with attempting to overthrow North Korea's regime using religion.\n\nIn what is believed to be a coerced statement, Lim soon admitted to the crimes after being sentenced to hard labour for life.\n\n\"There were rumours that he was affiliated with the uncle that Kim Jong Un had executed a few years back, and that was partly the reason for his incarceration,\" Jack Kim, a senior advisor with HanVoice, a Canada-based human rights organization that assists North Korean refugees, recently told CTV News.\n\nThen, two years and dozens of delicate diplomatic communications later, a Canadian delegation led by Daniel Jean, a national security advisor to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, travelled to Pyongyang this week to discuss Lim's case in person.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Prime Minister's Office spokesperson Cameron Ahmad told The Canadian Press on Tuesday.\n\nThat delegation was pivotal towards securing Lim's release, Ontario MPP Raymond Cho said.\n\n\"It is important that Kim Jong Un got the representatives from Canada, so we saved his face,\" Cho, who is Korean-Canadian, told CTV News. \"It is a very good gesture.\"\n\nSince being imprisoned, Lim's health was reportedly failing. He suffers from high blood pressure and allegedly lost nearly 40 kilograms while incarcerated.\n\nAccording to North Korea's news agency, Lim was released on \"sick bail.\"\n\nLim's release comes just weeks after North Korea freed 22-year-old American student Otto Warmbier, who was imprisoned in 2016 after allegedly trying to steal a propaganda poster. Brought home in a coma with obvious signs of torture, Warmbier died on June 19, just six days after arriving in the U.S.\n\n\"I am sure the North Koreans, they don't want to see the same thing with Reverend Hyeon Soo Lim, so that might be the deciding factor,\" Cho added.\n\nThere is, however, still no timeline for when Lim will be returned to Canada. His current whereabouts also remain unknown. As for his health issues, the North Korean government has not given any indication of just how sick the pastor has become.\n\nLim's parishioners say that have never lost faith and never stopped praying since their pastor was imprisoned in North Korea. But when word spread that Lim had finally been released on Wednesday, many met the news with disbelief.\n\n\"When I made the announcement this morning at service, they were like, 'Are you sure that's true?'\" associate pastor Charles Baik told CTV News.\n\nAmongst his family and parishioners, concerns still remain that speaking out about the case could jeopardize Lim's release. But it may come as some solace to Lim's congregation and family that when a U.S. diplomat recently went to North Korea to retrieve Warmbier, he reported seeing Lim and said that he was still able to stand.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son in the Toronto area, formed the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly 30 years ago, soon after emigrating to Canada from South Korea.", "time": "02:36:00"}
