"https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2017/08/13/our-pastor-released-pastor-greeted-with-cheers-chants-at-his-mississauga-church-after-more-than-two-years-in-north-korean-prison.html", "body": "\"Oh my god,\" one churchgoer said expectantly, clutching her phone and smiling, as all around her an ecstatic crowd waited to greet Hyeon Soo Lim on his return to the Light Presbyterian Church Sunday morning. Lim had spent 2 \u00bd years in North Korea prison. He was released earlier this week.\n\nWhen Hyeon Soo Lim walked through the front doors of the Light Presbyterian Church and looked at a crowd he hadn't seen since he was taken captive in North Korea in early 2015, the room erupted into applause and chants of \"our pastor\" in Korean. Lim, dressed in a black suit and tie with his hair closely shorn, raised both hands and smiled. And the crowd yelled louder, craning for a photo or a glance of the pastor they had been praying for.\n\n\"I don't know what's going to happen,\" Junghwe Kim had said minutes before, positioning herself next to a potted tree in the hopes of taking a photo of the 62-year-old Lim. \"Oh my god,\" she said expectantly, clutching her phone and smiling, as all around her, people held hands and waited, giddy and excited. She talked of her prayers and her fears, and how happy she was that North Korea, which normally \"does everything bad,\" did a \"very good\" thing in releasing her pastor. \"I hope he's recovering.\"\n\nMore than an hour before Lim arrived, church members stared out the window at the parking lot where Lim was due to arrive, waving at the phalanx of photographers and reporters who stood underneath a banner with their pastor's smiling face and a message: \"Welcome home Rev. Lim\"\n\nAnna Shin, who has been praying for Lim since the church found out he was captured during mission work in North Korea in January 2015, said she was \"way too excited\" for Sunday's reunion with the congregation. She said the pastor is known for his sense of humour and his ability to connect with all ages.\n\nLim will not give the Sunday church service, but is expected to thank the congregation, according to church spokesperson Richard Ha.\n\nOutside the church before the service, Lim told a group of reporters that he's proud to be a Canadian.\n\n\"We are extremely happy,\" said Lim's son, James, addressing the media at the church on Saturday. \"We're ecstatic and joyful that my father is home. It was surreal in the beginning to witness my father coming off of an airplane after 2 \u00bd years.\"\n\nWhile he was in prison, Lim had only ever seen his not yet 1-year-old granddaughter in pictures, James Lim said. \"It's been amazing to see him hold my daughter for the first time.\"\n\nJames Lim said his father is in good health and is recovering after the \"ordeal.\"\n\nThe elder Lim arrived in Toronto in the morning hours on Saturday. A spokesperson wouldn't specify his route back to the city from North Korea.\n\n\"Everyone was excited when we heard the news\" that he was freed, said Sam Shim, operations manager at Lim's church, Saturday afternoon. \"There was crying, joyful crying.\"\n\nAfter Lim was detained he was sentenced to life in a labour camp, with the regime there saying he had been conducting subversive actions against leader Kim Jong Un.\n\n\"He loved North Korea,\" said Shim, adding that the congregation was \"shocked\" when Lim was detained.\n\nLim's charitable work in North Korea was focused on food security and sustainable farming, the younger Lim said at the news conference.\n\nNorth Korea's Central Court granted Lim \"sick bail\" on humanitarian grounds on Wednesday.\n\nSweden helped facilitate his release as Canada does not have an embassy in North Korea.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed Lim's freedom Thursday afternoon in a written statement: \"The Government of Canada was actively in engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels. In particular, I want to thank Sweden, our protecting power in North Korea, for assisting us.\"\n\nIt has been reported that Lim was in poor health and had lost a lot of weight.\n\nIn a video provided by a spokesperson Saturday, a thin-looking Lim can be seen exiting what appears to be a government jet, smiling and hugging his family.\n\nA photo also provided by family shows him hugging his granddaughter on the tarmac.\n\nAt the press conference, James Lim joked that his father welcomed the weight loss, adding that he is \"in good spirits and is excited to come to church tomorrow. He hasn't seen the congregation in many years\"", "time": "16:06:00"}

been let go after two and a half years of being in detention\n\nHyeon Soo Lim is North Korea's longest held western prisoner in decades. He was \"released on sick bail\" by the country's top court for \"humanitarian\" reasons.\n\nLim's son, James Lim, received the news over the weekend that a plane was carrying senior Canadian officials, a doctor, while a letter addressed to the North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un was dispatched to Pyongyang \"at the last minute\".\n\nLim was imprisoned after being convicted of crimes against the state in December 2015. The 62-year-old's health deteriorated while in North Korean custody and experienced severe weight loss.\n\nThe release of Hyeon Soo Lim comes amid increased tensions on the Korean Peninsula just after US President Donald Trump threatened North Korea with \"fire and fury\", while Pyongyang said that it was considering a military strike against the US territory of Guam.\n\nWorth mentioning is that Lim was serving a life sentence of hard labor. Moreover, his family stepped up calls for his release since the death of American university student Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nWarmbier was detained in early 2016 and charged with attempting to steal a poster from his hotel. He died only six days after his release from North Korea due to brain injury that occurred while in custody. When he returned home to his family, he was in a vegetative state.\n\nSince then, the US State Department has announced a travel ban that will take effect next month, preventing almost all US citizens from visiting North Korea, with the only exception of journalists and humanitarian workers.", "time": "10:24:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2017/08/10/hyeon-soo-lims-arrest-in-north-korea-wont-stop-humanitarian-wo_a_23073372/", "body": "Update (8:08 a.m. ET): Relatives of a Canadian pastor released this week after more than two years in a North Korean prison say he is \"on his way home'' and they are anxious to be reunited with him.\n\nTORONTO -- An Ontario church congregation is celebrating news of the release of their pastor from a North Korean prison more than two years after he was arrested in the country.\n\nA decision from North Korea's central court freed Hyeon Soo Lim from the prison where he was serving a life sentence for anti-state activities, the country's Korean Central News Agency reported Wednesday.\n\nThe pastor's release, which came on the heels of an official visit from a Canadian government delegation, was described as \"sick bail\" by the news agency. No other details were provided.\n\nIn a brief statement issued early Thursday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he was \"pleased and relieved\" that Lim had been released.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention,\" said Trudeau.\n\nThe prime minister also thanked Sweden for its assistance in the matter but said \"operational security considerations\" prevents the government from discussing the matter further.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nCharges against him included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans, and helping American and South Korean efforts to help people defect from the north.\n\nWord of Lim's release drew members of his congregation to their church, just west of Toronto, where they were seen hugging and crying Wednesday morning.\n\nCharles Baik, an associate pastor with the church's English ministry, said members are ecstatic at the prospect of Lim's return.\n\n\"We're so happy he's been released, \" Baik said from outside the church.\n\nMissions will never stop, no matter where they may be.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe church has taken on numerous humanitarian projects in North Korea, one of which prompted Lim's last trip there in January 2015.\n\nFamily and friends previously said he was visiting an orphanage, nursery and nursing home in the country at the time of his arrest. The pastor had successfully travelled to North Korea more than 100 times over the past two decades, they added.\n\nBaik said the pastor's ordeal would not deter the church from future humanitarian projects in the country.\n\n\"Missions will never stop, no matter where they may be,\" he said.\n\nFamily members had urged the Canadian government to put pressure on North Korea to secure Lim's release.\n\nTheir calls for action took on fresh urgency in June following the death of Otto Warmbier, an American student who lived only one week after being released from North Korean custody due to health concerns.\n\nLim's own health was of concern to his family members, who had said the pastor needed medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nA Canadian delegation led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang this week to discuss Lim's case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, told The Canadian Press on Tuesday.\n\nNeither Ahmad nor Global Affairs responded to request for comment on Lim's release.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.", "time": "12:01:00"}

"1288147"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/asharq-al-awsat-english/world-news/north-korea-releases-canadian-pastor-two-year-imprisonment", "body": "Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim during a public interrogation at the People's Palace of Culture in Pyongyang, North Korea in 2015. (AFP)\n\nA Canadian pastor detained by North Korea in 2015 was released on Wednesday in a goodwill gesture by the Pyongyang, the official KCNA news agency said.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 61, was freed on \"sick bail\", the agency announced after a Canadian government delegation arrived in Pyongyang to discuss the case.\n\nThe office of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau earlier said that the delegation, led by his national security adviser, Daniel Jean, had arrived in Pyongyang on Tuesday.\n\nHe was serving a life sentence with hard labor. He was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nA court ordered Lim's release \"from the humanitarian viewpoint\", it said in a brief two-paragraph report.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation which Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nA Canadian delegation including national security adviser Daniel Jean visited Pyongyang this week to discuss the case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, in Ottawa before the release.\n\nLim's family told local media they had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nWarmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel during a tour, died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington worsen sharply. The North said earlier Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after US President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile program.\n\nAt the time of Lim's arrest, other members of the close-knit circle of ethnic Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States called him one of the most influential Christian missionaries operating in North Korea.\n\nHe had visited the country dozens of times, working with orphanages and nursing homes.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim Jong-Un.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\nLim told CNN last year that he spent his days in prison digging holes. \"I wasn't originally a laborer so the labor was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPyongyang views foreign missionaries with deep suspicion, though it allows some to undertake humanitarian work.\n\nSouth Korea, the US and others often accuse North Korea of using foreign detainees to wrest diplomatic concessions, and foreigners have said after their release that their declarations of guilt had been coerced while in North Korean custody.\n\nA number of Christian missionaries -- mostly ethnic Koreans who are US citizens -- have been arrested in the past, with some of them only allowed to return home after intervention by high-profile US political figures.\n\nTrudeau's spokesman Cameron Ahmad said the government considered Lim's health of \"utmost importance\" but did not give more details about the delegation.\n\nCanada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues. Lim met with the Swedish ambassador at least twice this year and met Canadian officials in December.\n\nAsharq Al-Awsat English\n\nAsharq Al-Awsat is the world's premier pan-Arab daily newspaper, printed simultaneously each day on four continents in 14 cities. Launched in London in 1978, Asharq Al-Awsat has established itself as the decisive publication on pan-Arab and international affairs, offering its readers in-depth analysis and exclusive editorials, as well as the most comprehensive coverage of the entire Arab world.\n\nMore Posts - Twitter - Facebook - Google Plus - YouTube\n\nFacebook Twitter Google+ Pinterest LinkedIn Related", "time": "12:04:00"}

congregation of one of Canada's largest churches welcomed their former pastor home on Sunday, the day after his return from North Korea, where he had been imprisoned for more than 2 1/2 years.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, sat in the front row of a packed worship hall at Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, a Toronto suburb. He was accompanied by family members, including his 1-year-old granddaughter, who was born while he was in captivity.\n\nIt was his first public appearance since his return to Canada on Saturday. Lim and Canadian officials have yet to discuss the details of his ordeal in North Korea, the reason for his arrest or what prompted his release from a life sentence of hard labor on charges that he sought to overthrow the Pyongyang regime.\n\n\"Reverend Lim's release was a miracle, work of God,\" said the Korean church's founder, emeritus pastor Chai Hoon Park.\n\nPark said Lim told him late on Saturday that he thought he would die as a martyr in North Korea and only learned of his release 10 minutes before he was let go.\n\n\"'They told me to go get changed. Then I was turned over to the Canadian delegation,'\" Park quoted Lim as telling him.\n\nLim's release, which was announced on Wednesday, came amid heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang, although authorities have not said there is any connection between his return and efforts to defuse the standoff over North Korea's nuclear program.\n\nLim's son James said at a Saturday news conference that the pastor was in \"good health\" but noted that the family planned to arrange for extended medical attention, including checkups.\n\n\"He is doing very well, considering everything he has gone through,\" he said.", "time": "16:58:00"}

"url": "http://www.nbcnews.com/news/north-korea/canada-confirms-pastor-hyeon-soo-lim-freed-north-korea-n791076", "body": "A Canadian pastor serving a life sentence in North Korea was freed Thursday on \"humanitarian\" grounds because of his health, the country's state-run news agency said.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim was convicted and sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of trying to overthrow the regime. He was first arrested in February 2015, but details about the 62-year-old's condition were not provided by the Korean Central News Agency, which said he was released on \"sick bail.\"\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed the release and said he was \"pleased and relieved\" the pastor \"will soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada.\"\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the Government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention,\" he added.\n\nDetails of when the pastor would return home were not released.\n\nThe sudden release of Lim, also known as Rim Hyon Su, comes amid flaring tensions between North Korea and the United States: On Tuesday, President Donald Trump told the isolated nation thatany threat to America would be met with \"fire and fury.\" Hours later, the North responded by saying it was \"seriously reviewing\" a plan to strike the U.S. Pacific territory of Guam.\n\nLim is affiliated with the Toronto-area Light Korean Presbyterian Church, one of the largest churches in Canada. Members have said he visited North Korea regularly since 1997 -- when the country was gripped by extreme famine -- to organize orphanages and nursing homes.\n\nBut Pyongyang charged that he used religion to undermine the government and sought to help North Korean citizens leave the country. In other cases of foreign missionaries being detained, the totalitarian government has accused them of anti-state crimes under the guise of offering humanitarian aid.\n\nAt his 2015 sentencing, Lim told the court: \"I deeply, deeply apologize from my heart for my indescribable treason.\"\n\nHuman rights groups say it's not uncommon for prisoners to provide a coerced confession.\n\nLim had been held with at least three other Americans who remain detained.\n\nRelated: Three Americans Still Held by North Korea Following Otto Warmbier's Release\n\nA fourth American, college student Otto Warmbier, was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor in March 2016. He mysteriously fell ill during his imprisonment -- the North claimed it was a combination of botulism and a sleeping pill -- and was released to a U.S. hospital, where he died in June.\n\nAfter Warmbier's death, the Lim family called for Canada to be more aggressive in ensuring their patriarch's release and questioned the status of his health.\n\n\"The family is very concerned at this point,\" family spokeswoman Lisa Pak said in June, according to Reuters. \"They are hoping the Canadian government will turn (efforts) up a few notches in terms of active diplomacy and really start engaging.\"\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea. But a Swedish ambassador visited Lim earlier this year on behalf of the country, and said he was in decent health, according to Pak.", "time": "10:21:00"}

negotiate the release of an imprisoned Canadian pastor, the media reported on Wednesday.\n\nAn official on Tuesday said Daniel Jean, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security and well-being remain of utmost importance to Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, media relations manager for the Prime Minister's Office.\n\nLim has been suffering from pastor was on his way home Thursday after being released from a North Korean prison where he spent the last two years, according to his family and the prime minister.\n\nNorth Korea's official KCNA news agency announced Hyeon Soo Lim's release Wednesday, saying he was freed on \"sick bail.\"\n\nThe announcement came after a Canadian government delegation led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security adviser Daniel Jean traveled to Pyongyang to discuss the 62-year-old's case.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Lisa Pak, a spokeswoman for the family, said in a statement.\n\nShe said the family was \"relieved, grateful, excited, and anxious to see him home.\"\n\nPak also thanked Canadian officials who \"worked behind the scenes with North Korean authorities\" to secure his release, as well as Swedish diplomats who assisted them.\n\nCanada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaking during a press conference at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Summit in Lima, November 20, 2016. (AFP/Raefael Zarauz)\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a statement that he was \"pleased and relieved\" to confirm Lim's release, adding that Lim would \"soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada.\"\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nLim's family had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nAmerican student Otto Warmbier speaks to reporters Monday, Feb. 29, 2016, in Pyongyang, North Korea. (AP Photo/Kim Kwang Hyon)\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington have grown increasingly tense. The North said Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after US President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile program.\n\nLim last year told CNN he spent his days in prison digging holes at an orchard. \"I wasn't originally a laborer so the labor was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPak said Lim has \"a long way to go in terms of... healing.\"\n\nTrudeau said Lim's \"health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention.\"", "time": "13:21:00"}

after being released from a North Korean prison where he spent the last two years, according to his family and the prime minister.\n\nNorth Korea's official KCNA news agency announced Hyeon Soo Lim's release Wednesday, saying he was freed on \"sick bail.\"\n\nThe announcement came after a Canadian government delegation led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean traveled to Pyongyang to discuss the 62-year-old's case.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Lisa Pak, a spokeswoman for the family, said in a statement.\n\nShe said the family was \"relieved, grateful, excited, and anxious to see him home.\"\n\nPak also thanked Canadian officials who \"worked behind the scenes with North Korean authorities\" to secure his release, as well as Swedish diplomats who assisted them.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a statement that he was \"pleased and relieved\" to confirm Lim's release, adding that Lim would \"soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada.\"\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nLim's family had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington have grown increasingly tense. "body": "Hyeon Soo Lim, 62, sat in the front row of a packed worship hall at Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, a Toronto suburb.\n\nThe congregation of one of Canada's largest churches welcomed their former pastor home on Sunday, the day after his return from North Korea, where he had been imprisoned for more than 2 1/2 years.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, sat in the front row of a packed worship hall at Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, a Toronto suburb. He was accompanied by family members, including his 1-year-old granddaughter, who was born while he was in captivity.\n\nIt was his first public appearance since his return to Canada on Saturday. Lim and Canadian officials have yet to discuss the details of his ordeal in North Korea, the reason for his arrest or what prompted his release from a life sentence of hard labor on charges that he sought to overthrow the Pyongyang regime.\n\n\"Reverend Lim's release was a miracle, work of God,\" said the Korean church's founder, emeritus pastor Chai Hoon Park.\n\nPark said Lim told him late on Saturday that he thought he would die as a martyr in North Korea and only learned of his release 10 minutes before he was let go.\n\n\"'They told me to go get changed. Then I was turned over to the Canadian delegation,'\" Park quoted Lim as telling him.\n\nLim's release, which was announced on Wednesday, came amid heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang, although authorities have not said there is any connection between his return and efforts to defuse the standoff over North Korea's nuclear program.\n\nLim's son James said at a Saturday news conference that the pastor was in \"good health\" but noted that the family planned to arrange for extended medical attention, including checkups.\n\n\"He is doing very well, considering everything he has gone through,\" he said.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "time": "16:51:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korean_Peninsula", "label": {"eng": "Korean Peninsula"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "317580"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Virginia", "wiki", "id": "1288147"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://wgno.com/2017/08/09/north-korea-releases-canadian-pastor-hyeon-soo-lim/", "body": "A Canadian pastor imprisoned in North Korea has been freed after two and a half years in detention.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, North Korea's longest-held western prisoner in decades, was \"released on sick bail\" Wednesday by the country's top court for \"humanitarian\" reasons, state-run news agency KCNA said.\n\nLim's son, James Lim, received word over the weekend that a plane carrying senior Canadian officials, a medical doctor, and a letter to North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un was dispatched to Pyongyang \"at the last minute,\" according to family spokeswoman Lisa Pak. The plane landed in the North Korean capital Monday.\n\nLim was serving a life sentence of hard labor after being convicted of crimes against the state in December 2015. The 62-year-old's health has deteriorated while in North Korean custody and the pastor has experienced \"dramatic\" weight loss, Pak said.\n\nLim's release comes amid heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula after US President Donald Trump threatened North Korea with \"fire and fury\" on Tuesday and Pyongyang said it was considering a military strike against the US territory of Guam.\n\nLim's family had stepped up calls for his release since the death of University of Virginia student Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nWarmbier was on a sightseeing tour of North Korea when he was detained in early 2016 and later charged with attempting to steal a propaganda poster from his hotel.\n\nHe died just six days after his release from North Korea due to a brain injury sustained while in custody. He was in a vegetative state when he returned home to his family near Cincinnati, Ohio.\n\nThe US State Department has since announced a travel ban that will take effect next month, preventing nearly all US citizens from visiting North Korea, with the exception of journalists and humanitarian workers.\n\nWhy Kim agreed to release Otto Warmbier\n\nIn letters to family, friends, and members of his church in Mississauga, Ontario, Lim has complained of stomach pain and high blood pressure.\n\nHis family has not been allowed to see him during his imprisonment, but have been able to send him letters and blood pressure medication via the Swedish embassy in Pyongyang, which often serves as an intermediary for prisoners from nations with no formal diplomatic ties to North Korea.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Pak said in statement to CNN.\n\n\"There is a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing. Therefore, in the meantime we ask the media for privacy as he reconnects with his loved ones and receives medical attention.\"\n\nThe family expressed gratitude to the Canadian, North Korean and Swedish governments.\n\n\"We want to thank the global community for the continued prayers and support and we also ask that the world does not forget the people of North Korea,\" the statement read.\n\nOpinion: How to put a stop to North Korea's brazen impunity\n\nLim detained in February 2015 while on a humanitarian mission in Rajin, North Korea, a family spokesperson said at the time. He was acting on behalf of the Light Korean Presbyterian Church, which he had led since 1986.\n\nAccording to his family, Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997, and his humanitarian efforts have included the founding by his church of a nursery, orphanage, and nursing home in the northeastern city of Rajin.\n\nIn a January 2016 interview with CNN in Pyongyang -- his first conversation with foreign media -- the Canadian said he was the sole prisoner in a labor camp, digging holes for eight hours a day, six days a week. At the time, he said he received regular medical care and three meals per day.\n\nAt least three US citizens remain in North Korean custody.\n\nBusinessman Kim Dong-chul was detained in October 2015 and is serving a 10-year sentence for espionage.\n\nKim Sang-duk, an academic also known as Tony Kim, was detained in April and is accused of \"hostile criminal acts,\" and researcher Kim Hak-song was detained in May and is also accused of \"hostile acts.\"", "time": "21:06:00"}

"http://www.metronews.ca/news/toronto/2017/08/10/canadian-pastor-freed-from-north-korean-prison-on-his-way-home-family.html", "body": "TORONTO -- Relatives of a Canadian pastor released this week after more than two years in a North Korean prison say he is \"on his way home\" and they are anxious to be reunited with him.\n\nThe Korean Central News Agency reported Wednesday that North Korea's central court had decided to free Hyeong Soo Lim, who was serving a life sentence for anti-state activities.\n\nThe pastor's release was described as \"sick bail,\" but no other details were given.\n\nIn a statement Thursday, a spokeswoman for his family said \"there is a long way to go\" in terms of Lim's healing and stressed the need for privacy as he receives unspecified medical attention.\n\nLisa Pak also said the family is grateful to the Canadian government and the Swedish embassy in North Korea for working behind the scenes to secure the pastor's freedom. She did not say when he was scheduled to arrive in Canada.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said Thursday he was \"pleased and relieved\" that Lim had been released.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention,\" Trudeau said in a brief statement.\n\nThe prime minister also thanked Sweden for its assistance in the matter but said \"operational security considerations\" prevent the government from discussing the matter further.\n\nA Canadian delegation led by Daniel Jean, Trudeau's national security adviser, was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang this week to discuss Lim's case.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nCharges against him included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans, and helping American and South Korean efforts to help people defect from the north.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe church has taken on numerous humanitarian projects in North Korea, one of which prompted Lim's last trip there in January 2015.\n\nMembers of the congregation celebrated news of his release Wednesday.\n\n-- With files from The Associated Press", "time": "12:22:00"}

We were driving back and just looking at the trees and the forest, he was so happy.\"\n\nLim is a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga and will attend a service at that church on Sunday in what will be his first public appearance.\n\nSpeaking with reporters, James Lim said he hasn't yet learned much about his father's time in captivity but knows that his spirit was never broken.\n\n\"He was telling me that he had about 2,700 meals on his own. Imagine that, being in isolation and having close to 3,000 meals all by yourself? But through those times he was able to spend time with God in solitude. I would say he tried to make the best of it,\" Lim told reporters.\n\nLim made 104 trips to North Korea to do humanitarian work prior to his arrest back in 2015.\n\nThe charges filed against him included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans, and assisting American and South Korean efforts to help people defect from the north.\n\nHis release on Wednesday came after a Canadian delegation visited North Korea to discuss his case with officials.", "time": "19:12:00"}

"http://www.keyt.com/health/north-korea-releases-canadian-pastor-hyeon-soo-lim/601864860", "body": "(CNN) - A Canadian pastor imprisoned in North Korea has been freed after two and a half years in detention.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, North Korea's longest-held western prisoner in decades, was \"released on sick bail\" Wednesday by the country's top court for \"humanitarian\" reasons, state-run news agency KCNA said.\n\nLim's son, James Lim, received word over the weekend that a plane carrying senior Canadian officials, a medical doctor, and a letter to North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un was dispatched to Pyongyang \"at the last minute,\" according to family spokeswoman Lisa Pak. The plane landed in the North Korean capital Monday.\n\nLim was serving a life sentence of hard labor after being convicted of crimes against the state in December 2015. The 62-year-old's health has deteriorated while in North Korean custody and the pastor has experienced \"dramatic\" weight loss, Pak said.\n\nLim's release comes amid heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula after US President Donald Trump threatened North Korea with \"fire and fury\" on Tuesday and Pyongyang said it was considering a military strike against the US territory of Guam.\n\nLim's family had stepped up calls for his release since the death of University of Virginia student Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nWarmbier was on a sightseeing tour of North Korea when he was detained in early 2016 and later charged with attempting to steal a propaganda poster from his hotel.\n\nHe died just six days after his release from North Korea due to a brain injury sustained while in custody. He was in a vegetative state when he returned home to his family near Cincinnati, Ohio.\n\nThe US State Department has since announced a travel ban that will take effect next month, preventing nearly all US citizens from visiting North Korea, with the exception of journalists and humanitarian workers.\n\nIn letters to family, friends, and members of his church in Mississauga, Ontario, Lim has complained of stomach pain and high blood pressure.\n\nHis family has not been allowed to see him during his imprisonment, but have been able to send him letters and blood pressure medication via the Swedish embassy in Pyongyang, which often serves as an intermediary for prisoners from nations with no formal diplomatic ties to North Korea.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Pak said in statement to CNN.\n\n\"There is a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing. Therefore, in the meantime we ask the media for privacy as he reconnects with his loved ones and receives medical attention.\"\n\nThe family expressed gratitude to the Canadian, North Korean and Swedish governments.\n\n\"We want to thank the global community for the continued prayers and support and we also ask that the world does not forget the people of North Korea,\" the statement read.\n\nLim detained in February 2015 while on a humanitarian mission in Rajin, North Korea, a family spokesperson said at the time. He was acting on behalf of the Light Korean Presbyterian Church, which he had led since 1986.\n\nAccording to his family, Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997, and his humanitarian efforts have included the founding by his church of a nursery, orphanage, and nursing home in the northeastern city of Rajin.\n\nIn a January 2016 interview with CNN in Pyongyang -- his first conversation with foreign media -- the Canadian said he was the sole prisoner in a labor camp, digging holes for eight hours a day, six days a week. At the time, he said he received regular medical care and three meals per day.\n\nAt least three US citizens remain in North Korean custody.\n\nBusinessman Kim Dong-chul was detained in October 2015 and is serving a 10-year sentence for espionage.\n\nKim Sang-duk, an academic also known as Tony Kim, was detained in April and is accused of \"hostile criminal acts,\" and researcher Kim Hak-song was detained in May and is also accused of \"hostile acts.\"", "time": "10:28:00"}

"Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://cyprus-mail.com/2017/08/09/north-korea-releases-jailed-canadian-pastor/", "body": "North Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence there on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury\".\n\nThe release came a day after Canadian officials said a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had travelled to North Korea to discuss the case of Hyeon Soo Lim, sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015.\n\nNorth Korea had accused Lim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Rim Hyon Su, a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail according to the decision of the Central Court of the DPRK on August 9, 2017, from the humanitarian viewpoint,\" KCNA said, using the country's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.\n\nThere was no obvious direct connection between the release and the standoff with the United States, but North Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington, and visits by high-profile Americans, with the detention and release of US citizens.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months.\n\nWarmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel during a tour, died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The US State Department said last week it would ban US nationals from travelling to the isolated country, beginning in September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury\".", "time": "12:06:00"}

"https://ca.news.yahoo.com/newsalert-north-korea-says-released-112513107.html", "body": "TORONTO -- An Ontario church congregation is celebrating news of the release of their pastor from a North Korean prison more than two years after he was arrested in the country.\n\nA decision from North Korea's central court freed Hyeon Soo Lim from the prison where he was serving a life sentence for anti-state activities, the country's Korean Central News Agency reported Wednesday.\n\nThe pastor's release, which came on the heels of an official visit from a Canadian government delegation, was described as \"sick bail\" by the news agency. No other details were provided.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nCharges against him included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans, and helping American and South Korean efforts to help people defect from the north.\n\nWord of Lim's release drew members of his congregation to their church, just west of Toronto, where they were seen hugging and crying Wednesday morning.\n\nCharles Baik, an associate pastor with the church's English ministry, said members are ecstatic at the prospect of Lim's return.\n\n\"We're so happy he's been released, \" Baik said from outside the church.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe church has taken on numerous humanitarian projects in North Korea, one of which prompted Lim's last trip there in January 2015.\n\nFamily and friends previously said he was visiting an orphanage, nursery and nursing home in the country at the time of his arrest. The pastor had successfully travelled to North Korea more than 100 times over the past two decades, they added.\n\nBaik said the pastor's ordeal would not deter the church from future humanitarian projects in the country.\n\n\"Missions will never stop, no matter where they may be,\" he said.\n\nFamily members had urged the Canadian government to put pressure on North Korea to secure Lim's release.\n\nTheir calls for action took on fresh urgency in June following the death of Otto Warmbier, an American student who lived only one week after being released from North Korean custody due to health concerns.\n\nLim's own health was of concern to his family members, who had said the pastor needed medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nA Canadian delegation led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang this week to discuss Lim's case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, told The Canadian Press on Tuesday.\n\nNeither Ahmad nor Global Affairs responded to request for comment on Lim's release.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.\n\n-- With files from The Associated Press\n\nBrennan Doherty and Michelle McQuigge , The Canadian Press", "time": "10:35:00"}

"Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/09/asia/north-korea-canada-pastor-hyeon-soo-lim/index.html", "body": "Story highlightsPastor Hyeon Soo Lim released by North Korean regime, family saysCanadian has been held prisoner for over two years; was sentenced to a life of hard labor in 2015\n\n(CNN)A Canadian pastor imprisoned in North Korea has been freed after two and a half years in detention.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, North Korea's longest-held western prisoner in decades, was \"released on sick bail\" Wednesday by the country's top court for \"humanitarian\" reasons, state-run news agency KCNA said. Lim's son, James Lim, received word over the weekend that a plane carrying senior Canadian officials, a medical doctor, and a letter to North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un was dispatched to Pyongyang \"at the last minute,\" according to family spokeswoman Lisa Pak. The plane landed in the North Korean capital Monday.Lim was serving a life sentence of hard labor after being convicted of crimes against the state in December 2015. The 62-year-old's health has deteriorated while in North Korean custody and the pastor has experienced \"dramatic\" weight loss, Pak said. Lim's release comes amid heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula after US President Donald Trump threatened North Korea with \"fire and fury\" on Tuesday and Pyongyang said it was considering a military strike against the US territory of Guam. Read MorePrevious medical releaseLim's family had stepped up calls for his release since the death of American university student Otto Warmbier in June. Warmbier was on a sightseeing tour of North Korea when he was detained in early 2016 and later charged with attempting to steal a propaganda poster from his hotel. He died just six days after his release from North Korea due to a brain injury sustained while in custody. He was in a vegetative state when he returned home to his family near Cincinnati, Ohio.The US State Department has since announced a travel ban that will take effect next month, preventing nearly all US citizens from visiting North Korea, with the exception of journalists and humanitarian workers.Why Kim agreed to release Otto WarmbierIllness in captivityIn letters to family, friends, and members of his church in Mississauga, Ontario, Lim has complained of stomach pain and high blood pressure.His family has not been allowed to see him during his imprisonment, but have been able to send him letters and blood pressure medication via the Swedish embassy in Pyongyang, which often serves as an intermediary for prisoners from nations with no formal diplomatic ties to North Korea.\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Pak said in statement to CNN. \"There is a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing. Therefore, in the meantime we ask the media for privacy as he reconnects with his loved ones and receives medical attention.\"The family expressed gratitude to the Canadian, North Korean and Swedish governments.\"We want to thank the global community for the continued prayers and support and we also ask that the world does not forget the people of North Korea,\" the statement read.Opinion: How to put a stop to North Korea's brazen impunityHard laborLim detained in February 2015 while on a humanitarian mission in Rajin, North Korea, a family spokesperson said at the time. He was acting on behalf of the Light Korean Presbyterian Church, which he had led since 1986.According to his family, Lim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997, and his humanitarian efforts have included the founding by his church of a nursery, orphanage, and nursing home in the northeastern city of Rajin.In a January 2016 interview with CNN in Pyongyang -- his first conversation with foreign media -- the Canadian said he was the sole prisoner in a labor camp, digging holes for eight hours a day, six days a week. At the time, he said he received regular medical care and three meals per day. Left behindAt least three US citizens remain in North Korean custody. Businessman Kim Dong-chul was detained in October 2015 and is serving a 10-year sentence for espionage. Kim Sang-duk, an academic also known as Tony Kim, was detained in April and is accused of \"hostile criminal acts,\" and researcher Kim Hak-song was detained in May and is also accused of \"hostile acts.\"", "time": "11:33:00"}

released from prison in North Korea this week has returned to Canada.\n\nFamily spokeswoman Lisa Pak says Hyeong Soo Lim had a \"private reunion\" with his family late Saturday morning.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, had been serving a life sentence with hard labour for anti-state activities when the North Korean government released him on what it {"timeCrawl": "10:31:00", "eventUri": "eng-3346886", "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "id": 41}, {"wgt": 100, "uri": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/1a0/news/politics/article35918720.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/web-canadian-pastor.JPG", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-10", "originalArticle": null, "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario", "location": {"country": {"label": {"eng": "Canada"}, "type": "country"}, "label": {"eng": "Ontario"}, "type": "place"}, "type": "loc"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Trudeau", "label": {"eng": "Justin Trudeau"}, "score": 4, "type": "person", "id": "306058"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Jong-un", "label": {"eng": "Kim Jong-un"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "312664"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_North_Korea", "label": {"eng": "Human rights in North Korea"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "314012"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korean_War", "label": {"eng": "Korean War"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "332780"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koreans_in_China", "label": {"eng": "Koreans in China"}, "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "id": "624080"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyeon_Soo_Lim", "label": {"eng": "Hyeon Soo Lim"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288147"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/ottawa-sweden-helped-secure-pastors-release-from-north-korea-trudeau-signals/article35934205/", "body": "Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Thursday hailed the release of a Toronto pastor in North Korea, signalling his national security adviser helped get Hyeon Soo Lim out of prison with the aid of Sweden.\n\n\"I am pleased and relieved to confirm that Pastor Lim has been released from jail in North Korea and that he will soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada,\" Mr. Trudeau said in an early morning statement.\n\nThis came after North Korea's state media reported Wednesday that Mr. Lim, serving a life sentence in a labour camp, was freed on \"sick bail.\"\n\nMr. Trudeau said little about what led to Mr. Lim's release - \"operational security considerations prevent us from discussing the matter further\" - but noted the role of Daniel Jean, his national security adviser, and Sweden.\n\n\"The government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels,\" Mr. Trudeau said.\n\n\"In particular, I want to thank Sweden, our protecting power in North Korea, for assisting us,\" he added.\n\n\"This week, a Canadian government delegation led by Daniel Jean, my special envoy, travelled to Pyongyang, North Korea, to discuss Pastor Lim's case. Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention.\"\n\nMr. Lim's release comes at a time when Pyongyang is at the centre of high-pitched international tension over its nuclear-missile program that has dominated attention from Washington to Beijing.\n\nIt's unclear whether the international tensions swirling around North Korea had any effect on the case of Mr. Lim, about whom family and friends were growing increasingly worried.\n\nIt's possible that Mr. Lim's release might be North Korea's way of sending a goodwill message at a time of high tension, to try to portray itself as a reasonable country that can negotiate, said Steven Denney, a doctoral fellow at the Munk School of Global Affairs' Asian Institute.\n\n\"I think that North Korea understood that it was on thinner ice than usual,\" he said, after the case of Otto Warmbier, an American University student who fell into a coma while imprisoned in North Korea - he was released June 13, but died six days later. It's possible the regime is being more cautious with Mr. Lim's health problems, Mr. Denney said.\n\nPyongyang had reason to avoid a repeat of what happened to Mr. Warmbier.\n\n\"That incident met with major U.S. and international backlash against North Korea. It catalyzed discussions over additional human-rights-focused sanctions and prompted countries to re-evaluate their policies on tourism to the North,\" said Andrea Berger, senior research associate at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies.\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump set a confrontational tone Tuesday, when he said the United States would respond to North Korean threats \"with fire and fury the world has never seen.\"\n\nThat heightened speculation the United States was moving toward war with North Korea, though U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson sought to dial back the fears of imminent military conflict as he flew to Guam on Wednesday.\n\nHe told reporters that Mr. Trump was sending \"a strong message to North Korea in language that [North Korean leader] Kim Jong-un would understand.\" Even so, the United States has in recent weeks delivered a steady drumbeat of warnings to Pyongyang that it must stand down from its pursuit of functional warheads for long-range nuclear missiles.There has also been tension between Washington and China, as Mr. Trump repeatedly pressed Beijing to use its influence to rein in its neighbour.\n\nChina signalled what could be a major shift by casting a United Nations Security Council vote on Saturday to impose sanctions on North Korea. If China enforces those sanctions, it would have a major impact on its neighbour, as most of North Korea's trade goes through China. The UN vote appeared to mark a new willingness by Beijing to openly pressuring its neighbour with punitive measures.\n\nChina's influence has always been crucial in diplomacy with North Korea - few other countries have functioning relationships with Pyongyang. Canada has no direct diplomatic relations with Pyongyang, but Mr. Trudeau's Liberal government is actively working to warm political and economic ties with Beijing. Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland was in China on Wednesday for formal talks with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, arriving after Mr. Jean and the delegation were already in North Korea.\n\nJack Kim, special adviser to HanVoice, a Canadian non-profit organization that advocates for North Korean human rights, said it is not clear if there was a quid pro quo between Canada and North Korea for Mr. Lim's release. However, he said Mr. Jean's visit to Pyongyang may have been enough for the North Koreans.\n\n\"What they usually want is a high-profile official going to North Korea. ... Daniel Jean, in the Canadian sense, does fit that bill,\" Mr. Kim said. \"It's kind of a show of respect to the North Korean regime that these foreign officials are coming to fetch these incarcerated folks out.\"\n\nMr. Kim said the government's decision to send Mr. Jean - as opposed to a sitting legislator or even a cabinet minister - to Pyongyang was a \"good compromise\" in an effort to not give into the North Koreans.\n\nMr. Lim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada and travelled to North Korea regularly on humanitarian missions, was sentenced by the country's Supreme Court in December, 2015, to a lifetime of hard labour after being accused of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\nIn his early 60s, Mr. Lim is said to suffer from high blood pressure and is believed to have lost a significant amount of weight since his capture.\n\nMr. Lim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death of Mr. Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months.\n\nMr. Warmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel during a tour, died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nStaff and members of Mississauga's Light Korean Presbyterian Church had long been praying for Mr. Lim's release and well-being. Assistant pastor John Bae arrived Wednesday morning for 5:30 prayers and found out Mr. Lim had been let go an hour later.\n\n\"We were praying so hard for good news,\" he told The Globe and Mail shortly after removing a \"Bring Lim Home\" sign from his office door. \"We're thankful for the Canadian government's work.\"\n\nRaymond Cho, a Progressive Conservative member of the Ontario legislature who has known Mr. Lim for 20 years, said he has not heard any official word about the pastor's release but believes failing health played a major factor.\n\n\"His health must be pretty bad, I suspect,\" Mr. Cho said before Mr. Trudeau's comments Thursday.\n\nMr. Cho said North Korea could be trying to \"save face\" in the international community by releasing Mr. Lim.\n\n\"I don't think it will help if [Mr. Lim] becomes any more sick and dies there. At this stage, North Korea is getting more and more isolated after this continued missile testing and the nuclear-arms program,\" he said.\n\n\"Whatever the reason, I'm exceedingly happy he's coming home.\"\n\nConservative Senator Yonah Martin, who is ethnically Korean, had previously lobbied for Mr. Lim to be freed. \"I'm relieved,\" she said, following the news of Mr. Lim's release.\n\nShe said Mr. Warmbier's death had been a \"catalyst\" for the release of the Canadian pastor.\n\nMs. Martin said Mr. Lim had lost more than 20 kilograms. Last year, Mr. Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nHis family had sent him needed medication but was worried he was not receiving it. A letter sent by Mr. Lim to his family further raised concern that he was unwell.\n\n\"The tone in the letter,\" Ms. Martin said, gave \"the sense that his health was definitely being affected.\n\n\"How could it not? Being away from family, away for such a long period of time after being isolated, being under watch and under hard labour in North Korea.\"", "time": "10:31:00"}

"type": "wiki", "id": "1288147"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.reddeeradvocate.com/news/canadian-pastor-freed-in-north-korea/", "body": "TORONTO -- An Ontario church congregation is celebrating news of the release of their pastor from a North Korean prison more than two years after he was arrested in the country.\n\nA decision from North Korea's central court freed Hyeon Soo Lim from the prison where he was serving a life sentence for anti-state activities, the country's Korean Central News Agency reported Wednesday.\n\nThe pastor's release, which came on the heels of an official visit from a Canadian government delegation, was described as \"sick bail\" by the news agency. No other details were provided.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nCharges against him included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans, and helping American and South Korean efforts to help people defect from the north.\n\nWord of Lim's release drew members of his congregation to their church, just west of Toronto, where they were seen hugging and crying Wednesday morning.\n\nCharles Baik, an associate pastor with the church's English ministry, said members are ecstatic at the prospect of Lim's return.\n\n\"We're so happy he's been released, \" Baik said from outside the church.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe church has taken on numerous humanitarian projects in North Korea, one of which prompted Lim's last trip there in January 2015.\n\nFamily and friends previously said he was visiting an orphanage, nursery and nursing home in the country at the time of his arrest. The pastor had successfully travelled to North Korea more than 100 times over the past two decades, they added.\n\nBaik said the pastor's ordeal would not deter the church from future humanitarian projects in the country.\n\n\"Missions will never stop, no matter where they may be,\" he said.\n\nFamily members had urged the Canadian government to put pressure on North Korea to secure Lim's release.\n\nTheir calls for action took on fresh urgency in June following the death of Otto Warmbier, an American student who lived only one week after being released from North Korean custody due to health concerns.\n\nLim's own health was of concern to his family members, who had said the pastor needed medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nA Canadian delegation led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang this week to discuss Lim's case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, told The Canadian Press on Tuesday.\n\nNeither Ahmad nor Global Affairs responded to request for comment on Lim's release.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.", "time": "20:45:00"}

"http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/canadian-pastor-on-way-home-after-north-korea-release/article/499671", "body": "A Canadian pastor was on his way home Thursday after being released from a North Korean prison where he spent the last two years, according to his family and the prime minister.\n\nNorth Korea's official KCNA news agency announced Hyeon Soo Lim's release Wednesday, saying he was freed on \"sick bail.\"\n\nThe announcement came after a Canadian government delegation led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean traveled to Pyongyang to discuss the 62-year-old's case.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Lisa Pak, a spokeswoman for the family, said in a statement.\n\nShe said the family was \"relieved, grateful, excited, and anxious to see him home.\"\n\nPak also thanked Canadian officials who \"worked behind the scenes with North Korean authorities\" to secure his release, as well as Swedish diplomats who assisted them.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a statement that he was \"pleased and relieved\" to confirm Lim's release, adding that Lim would \"soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada.\"\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nLim's family had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington have grown increasingly tense. The North said Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after US President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile program.\n\nLim last year told CNN he spent his days in prison digging holes at an orchard. \"I wasn't originally a laborer so the labor was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPak said Lim has \"a long way to go in terms of... healing.\"\n\nTrudeau said Lim's \"health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention.\"", "time": "11:50:00"}

"http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/family-of-pastor-released-from-north-korea-says-his-faith-has-grown-stronger-1.3543404", "body": "The son of the Toronto-area pastor who served more than two years of a life sentence with hard labour in North Korea for anti-state activities says his father will worship with his congregation on Sunday morning, following a day of rest and reunion with his family.\n\n\"It was surreal from the beginning to witness my father coming off an airplane after two-and-a-half years,\" James Lim told reporters at a press conference on Saturday. \"His faith has grown stronger.\"\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, landed in Ontario on Saturday morning, according to the family's spokesperson Lisa Pak. He had not seen his relatives in person since his 2015 arrest on a missionary trip where he is said to have been mainly working to improve food security within the insular communist state.\n\nNorth Korean authorities freed Hyeon Soo Lim earlier this week. A six-member Canadian diplomatic envoy travelled to Pyongyang to help secure his release.\n\nJames Lim said his father first embraced his mother, and then went straight towards his infant granddaughter, who was born while he was imprisoned, when the family was reunited.\n\n\"It was just incredible. Just to see two people that I love more than anybody else in the world finally meet and embrace,\" James Lim said. \"You play in your head many times what that moment is going to be like. It's far greater than anything you could have imagined.\"\n\nPak said the family still does not know why North Korean authorities released Hyeon Soo Lim, or what led to his arrest. She estimates the pastor travelled to the country over 110 times to do similar work over the course of two decades.\n\n\"My best guess is that they were concerned about his health, and so they released him,\" Pak said.\n\nJames Lim said the family relied heavily on their Christian values and never gave up hope during Hyeon Soo Lim's imprisonment. He said watching his father's taped confession on North Korean state television and the death of U.S. university student Otto Warmbier tested the family's faith.\n\nWarmbier spent 17 months in a North Korean prison for allegedly taking a propaganda poster. He fell into a coma, and was medically evacuated to the U.S. on June 13. Warmbier died days later.\n\n\"The thing that we were really concerned about was the terrible and unfortunate passing of Otto Warmbier. That was unprecedented,\" James Lim said. \"That placed a huge amount of not only burden, but urgency to push the government.\"\n\nJames Lim said his father is grateful to Canadian officials for their efforts to bring him home, adding that he is generally in good spirit and health. He said he is probably looking forward to returning to his typically Canadian pleasures; coffee, doughnuts, and ice fishing.\n\n\"He is so happy to be home,\" James Lim said. \"I think now more than ever, he has never felt more Canadian.\"", "time": "21:22:00"}

Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence there on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury\".\n\nThe release came a day after Canadian officials said a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had travelled to North Korea to discuss the case of Hyeon Soo Lim, sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015.\n\nNorth Korea had accused Lim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Rim Hyon Su, a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail according to the decision of the Central Court of the DPRK on August 9, 2017, from the humanitarian viewpoint,\" KCNA said, using the country's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.\n\nThere was no obvious direct connection between the release and the standoff with the United States, but North Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington, and visits by high-profile Americans, with the detention and release of U.S. citizens.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months.\n\nWarmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel during a tour, died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The U.S. State Department said last week it would ban U.S. nationals from travelling to the isolated country, beginning in September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the U.S. Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury\".\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "time": "12:19:00"}

the North's regime. agency announced after a Canadian government delegation arrived in Pyongyang to discuss the case.\n\nA court ordered Lim's release \"from the humanitarian viewpoint\", it said in a brief two-paragraph report.\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation which Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nA Canadian delegation including national security adviser Daniel Jean visited Pyongyang this week to discuss the case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, in Ottawa before the release.\n\nLim's family told local media they had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington worsen sharply. The North said earlier Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after US President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile programme.\n\nAt the time of Lim's arrest, other members of the close-knit circle of ethnic Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States called him one of the most influential Christian missionaries operating in North Korea.\n\nHe had visited the country dozens of times, working with orphanages and nursing homes.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim Jong-Un.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\nLim told CNN last year that he spent his days in prison digging holes. \"I wasn't originally a labourer so the labour was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPyongyang views foreign missionaries with deep suspicion, though it allows some to undertake humanitarian work.\n\nA number of Christian missionaries -- mostly ethnic Koreans who are US citizens -- have been arrested in the past, with some of them only allowed to return home after intervention by high-profile US political figures.", "time": "11:56:00"}

"http://lethbridgeherald.com/news/national-news/2017/08/09/north-korea-says-it-released-canadian-pastor-ontario-congregation-celebrates-news/", "body": "By Brennan Doherty and Michelle McQuigge, The Canadian Press on August 9, 2017.\n\nTORONTO - An Ontario church congregation is celebrating news of the release of their pastor from a North Korean prison more than two years after he was arrested in the country.\n\nA decision from North Korea's central court freed Hyeon Soo Lim from the prison where he was serving a life sentence for anti-state activities, the country's Korean Central News Agency reported Wednesday.\n\nThe pastor's release, which came on the heels of an official visit from a Canadian government delegation, was described as \"sick bail\" by the news agency. No other details were provided.\n\nLim, a pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., had been sentenced by a North Korean court to life in prison with hard labour for what it called crimes against the state.\n\nCharges against him included harming the dignity of the supreme leadership, trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, disseminating negative propaganda about the North to overseas Koreans, and helping American and South Korean efforts to help people defect from the north.\n\nWord of Lim's release drew members of his congregation to their church, just west of Toronto, where they were seen hugging and crying Wednesday morning.\n\nCharles Baik, an associate pastor with the church's English ministry, said members are ecstatic at the prospect of Lim's return.\n\n\"We're so happy he's been released, \" Baik said from outside the church.\n\nLim, who has a wife and son living in the Toronto area, started the Light Korean Presbyterian Church nearly three decades ago, shortly after he emigrated from South Korea.\n\nHe grew the congregation from about a dozen people in 1986 to more than 3,000 members. He also runs a smaller church in downtown Toronto that caters to young people.\n\nThe church has taken on numerous humanitarian projects in North Korea, one of which prompted Lim's last trip there in January 2015.\n\nFamily and friends previously said he was visiting an orphanage, nursery and nursing home in the country at the time of his arrest. The pastor had successfully travelled to North Korea more than 100 times over the past two decades, they added.\n\nBaik said the pastor's ordeal would not deter the church from future humanitarian projects in the country.\n\n\"Missions will never stop, no matter where they may be,\" he said.\n\nFamily members had urged the Canadian government to put pressure on North Korea to secure Lim's release.\n\nTheir calls for action took on fresh urgency in June following the death of Otto Warmbier, an American student who lived only one week after being released from North Korean custody due to health concerns.\n\nLim's own health was of concern to his family members, who had said the pastor needed medication to manage his blood pressure.\n\nA Canadian delegation led by Daniel Jean, the national security adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, was in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang this week to discuss Lim's case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's Office, told The Canadian Press on Tuesday.\n\nNeither Ahmad nor Global Affairs responded to request for comment on Lim's release.\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and has advised against all travel there.", "time": "18:09:00"}

churches in Canada, was sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 for what North Korea says was an attempt to overthrow the regime.\n\nThe delegation is headed by Daniel Jean, the June death of American student Otto Warmbier who had been held in North Korea for 17 months. Warmbier died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after he was released in a coma. Canadian officials visited Lim in December 2016.\n\nIn addition to Canada\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Lim, North Korea is holding three Americans.\n\nLim\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Toronto-area church has said Lim visited North Korea more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home.\n\nLast year, Lim told CNN he spends eight hours a day digging holes at a labor camp where he has not seen any other prisoners.\n\nThe UN Security Council imposed new sanctions on North Korea at the weekend over its continued missile tests, and U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday warned the country would be met with \u00e2\u0080\u009cfire and fury\u00e2\u0080\u009d if it threatens the United Sates.", "time": "22:52:00"}
