nursing homes.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim Jong-Un. Jang Song-Thaek was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\nLim told CNN last year that he now spends his days in prison digging holes.\n\nPyongyang views foreign missionaries with deep suspicion, though it allows some to undertake humanitarian work.\n\nA number of Christian missionaries -- mostly ethnic Koreans who are US citizens -- have been arrested in the past, with some of them only allowed to return home after intervention by high-profile US political figures.", "time": "00:52:00"}

announcement came after a Canadian government delegation led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean traveled to Pyongyang to discuss the 62-year-old's case.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his grand daughter for the first time,\" Lisa Pak, a spokeswoman for the family, said in a statement.\n\nShe said the family was \"relieved, grateful, excited, and anxious to see him home.\"\n\nPak also thanked Canadian officials who \"worked behind the scenes with North Korean authorities\" to secure his release, as well as Swedish diplomats who assisted them.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a statement that he was \"pleased and relieved\" to confirm Lim's release, adding that Lim would \"soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada.\"\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nLim's family had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington have grown increasingly tense. health and well-being remain of utmost importance to Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, media relations manager for the Prime Minister's Office.\n\nLim has been suffering from high blood pressure and stomach pains, according to letters to his friends. His family has urged the Canadian Prime Minister to save his life.\n\nThe 62-year-old Canadian Korean pastor was arrested in 2015 and charged with harming the dignity of the supreme leadership and trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system.\n\nA Canadian government official said Jean was leading the delegation as Trudeau's special envoy, and while his focus was the release of Lim, he would also \"discuss other issues of regional concern\".\n\nThe Canadian delegation arrived on the same day US President Donald Trump warned that Pyongyang would be met \"with fire and fury and, frankly, power the likes of which the world has never seen before\", if it does not stop threatening the US.\n\nThe official said the timing of the delegation's visit was based on the condition of Lim, and not related to the increasing world pressure associated with Pyongyang's missile tests and last weekend's imposition of further sanctions by the UN.\n\n\u00a9 2017 IANS India Private Limited. "http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/pastor-north-korea-release-1.4245012", "body": "Trudeau adviser in North Korea to seek Canadian pastor's release\n\nToronto-area pastor Hyeon Soo Lim is expected back on Canadian soil today after more than two years in detention in North Korea.\n\nLim is expected to land in Ontario this morning aboard a Canadian military aircraft, completing his journey home after he was freed from Pyongyang earlier this week. It's not clear whether he will arrive in Toronto or at another airport.\n\nHe is expected to be reunited with his family at the airport. They have not seen each other in person since the pastor was arrested in 2015 and sentenced to a life of hard labour in prison for crimes against the state.\n\nThe six-member Canadian delegation that secured Lim's release was led by Daniel Jean, who serves as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security and intelligence adviser. The delegation travelled with the Presbyterian reverend.\n\nThey flew to the Yokota Airbase in Japan from Pyongyang on Thursday, after North Korea's Central Court granted Lim \"sick bail\" on humanitarian grounds.\n\nFrom there, the Royal Canadian Air Force CC-144 Challenger aircraft flew across the Pacific Ocean, making stopovers in Guam, Honolulu and Vancouver.\n\nLim's release comes after the Canadian delegation was dispatched from Ottawa to the reclusive regime last Saturday. The team spent 40 hours in Pyongyang, from Tuesday evening until Thursday morning, holding talks with senior North Korean officials, and left the capital with Lim after he was freed.\n\nThe 62-year-old Toronto pastor with the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., is planning to attend church service this weekend. His colleague, Rev. Jang Bae, told The Canadian Press in an email that Lim \"will be attending service this Sunday.\"\u200b", "time": "14:54:00"}

"http://london.ctvnews.ca/freed-missisauga-pastor-describes-overwhelming-loneliness-in-north-korean-prison-1.3543937", "body": "Pastor Hyeon Soo Lim waves to the congregation as he arrives at the Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., Sunday, August 13, 2017. Lim was released last week from prison in North Korea, where he had been serving a life sentence with hard labour for anti-state activities. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Frank Gunn\n\nA Canadian pastor freed from a North Korean prison was met with cheers as he waded through a mob of people at church Sunday morning, making his first public appearance since arriving home.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim attended the Sunday service at the Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, where he works as a pastor.\n\nHe had been serving a life sentence of hard labour for alleged anti-state activities when he was released last week on what the North Korean government described as \"sick bail.\"\n\nOutside the church before the service, Lim told a group of reporters that he's proud to be a Canadian.\n\nHe made the appearance just one day after arriving home on a small government aircraft Saturday morning.\n\nCTV News obtained a copy of the address Lim gave to the church members.\n\nIn it he says he read more than 100 books, ate 2,757 meals in solitude and endured overwhelming loneliness.\n\nDuring the winter, Lim says he had to dig holes and worked in a coal storage facility.\n\nHe suffered frostbitten fingers and toes.\n\nLim told the congregation that it was by the grace of God that he was freed.", "time": "17:15:00"}

"https://www.nknews.org/2017/08/north-korea-releases-canadian-citizen-on-humanitarian-grounds/", "body": "North Korea has released Canadian citizen Lim Hyeon Soo from custody for humanitarian reasons, according to the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) on Wednesday.\n\nLim, a Reverend at the Light Presbyterian Korean Church in Toronto, was sentenced to a life of hard labor by the North Korean regime in December of 2015 for numerous charges, including attempting to overthrow the North Korean government.\n\n\"Rim Hyon Su, (Lim Hyeon Soo) a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail according to the decision of the Central Court of the DPRK on August 9, 2017, from the humanitarian viewpoint,\" KCNA reported in Korean.\n\nLim's release comes following the visit of a delegation from the Canadian Government to Pyongyang on Tuesday, which was led by Daniel Jean - a national security advisor to the Prime Minister of Canada.\n\nLim went missing during a trip to North Korea in January 2015 after traveling to the country in order to continue working on humanitarian projects previously established with the blessing of the North Korean government.\n\nIn March 2015 it emerged that Lim had been arrested, and he was subsequently sentenced to a life sentence of hard labor in December of the same year for numerous charges, including what DPRK authorities claimed was an attempt to overthrow the government.\n\nHe is the second foreign citizen to be released on what the North Koreans have termed \"humanitarian grounds\" in 2017, following the release of U.S. citizen Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nWarmbier had been arrested in Pyongyang in early 2016 after he walked into a staff-only area of the Yanggakdo International Hotel in Pyongyang and took down a political slogan from a wall. He was subsequently sentenced to 15 years of hard labor.\n\nWarmbier was in a coma when released by North Korean authorities, which according to the DPRK, was due to a rare case of botulism he contracted shortly after his sentencing in 2016.\n\nDoctors at the University of Cincinnati Medical Center assessing Warmbier's condition on his return concluded that the U.S. citizen had suffered significant brain damage and no signs of botulism were detected. On June 19, shortly after his release, Warmbier passed away at the age of 22.\n\nThree American citizens remain in custody in North Korea.\n\nEdited by Oliver Hotham\n\nPhoto: File\n\nNorth Korea has released Canadian citizen Lim Hyeon Soo from custody for humanitarian reasons, according to the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) on Wednesday. "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/09/north-korea-canada-pastor-released-life-sentence", "body": "Faced hard labour after 2015 arrest for allegedly meddling in state affairs\n\nA Canadian pastor serving a life sentence with hard labour in North Korea has been released on medical parole as a humanitarian gesture, the official KCNA news agency said.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 61, was freed on \"sick bail\", the agency announced after a Canadian government delegation arrived in Pyongyang to discuss the case.\n\nA court ordered Lim's release \"from the humanitarian viewpoint\", it said in a brief two-paragraph report.\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation which Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nA Canadian delegation, including the national security adviser Daniel Jean, visited Pyongyang this week to discuss the case.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and wellbeing remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,\" said Cameron Ahmad, a spokesman for the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, in Ottawa before the release.\n\nLim's family told local media they had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of the American student Otto Warmbier in June, just days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as relations with Washington worsen sharply. The North said earlier Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile programme.\n\nAt the time of Lim's arrest, other members of the close-knit circle of ethnic Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States called him one of the most influential Christian missionaries operating in North Korea.\n\nHe had visited the country dozens of times, working with orphanages and nursing homes.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim Jong-Un.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\nLim told CNN last year that he spent his days in prison digging holes. \"I wasn't originally a labourer so the labour was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPyongyang views foreign missionaries with deep suspicion, though it allows some to undertake humanitarian work.\n\nA number of Christian missionaries - mostly ethnic Koreans who are US citizens - have been arrested in the past, with some of them only allowed to return home after intervention by high-profile US political figures.", "time": "13:48:00"}

"Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4774718/index.html", "body": "BEIJING/SEOUL, Aug 9 (Reuters) - North Korea freed a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence there on humanitarian grounds, the official KCNA news agency said on Wednesday, just hours after the United States warned it would counter any threat from the North with \"fire and fury\".\n\nThe release came a day after Canadian officials said a delegation led by the country's national security adviser had travelled to North Korea to discuss the case of Hyeon Soo Lim, sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015.\n\nNorth Korea had accused Lim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\n\"Rim Hyon Su, a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail according to the decision of the Central Court of the DPRK on August 9, 2017, from the humanitarian viewpoint,\" KCNA said, using the country's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.\n\nThere was no obvious direct connection between the release and the standoff with the United States, but North Korea has in the past attracted the attention of Washington, and visits by high-profile Americans, with the detention and release of U.S. citizens.\n\nLim's family had become more concerned for his welfare since the death in June of American student Otto Warmbier, who had been held in North Korea for 17 months.\n\nWarmbier, sentenced last year to 15 years' hard labour for trying to steal a propaganda item from his hotel during a tour, died in a Cincinnati hospital just days after being released in a coma. The circumstances of his death remain unclear.\n\nNorth Korea is still holding three Americans. The U.S. State Department said last week it would ban U.S. nationals from travelling to the isolated country, beginning in September.\n\nLim's Toronto-area church has said he visited the North more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Last year, Lim told CNN he spent eight hours a day digging holes at a labour camp where he had not seen any other prisoners.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea said it was considering plans for a missile strike on the U.S. Pacific territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump told the North that any threat to the United States would be met with \"fire and fury\". (Reporting by Ben Blanchard and Soyoung Kim,; Editing by Clarence Fernandez and Nick Macfie)", "time": "11:42:00"}

"https://www.christiantoday.com/article/canadian.pastor.lim.is.released.from.prison.in.north.korea.state.news.agency.says/111669.htm?email=1", "body": "A Canadian pastor imprisoned in North Korea since 2015 has been released on humanitarian grounds because of his ill health, according to the country's state news agency.\n\nNews of the release of 62-year-old Hyeon Soo Lim - also known as Rim Hyon Su -comes just hours after a high-level Canadian delegation, led by the prime minister's national security adviser, had arrived in the country in the hope of intervening in his case.\n\n'Rim Hyon Su, a Canadian civilian, was released on sick bail according to the decision of the Central Court of the DPRK on August 9, 2017 from the humanitarian viewpoint,' said the KCNA news agency said Wednesday, using the pariah state's official name, Democratic People's Republic of Korea.\n\n'He had been under the penalty of indefinite hard labor as he conducted hostile deeds against the DPRK,' the agency added.\n\nDetained in early 2015, Lim was sentenced to a life of hard labour on December 16, 2015 for 'harming the dignity of the supreme leader,' 'trying to use religion to destroy North Korea' and 'assisting North Koreans escape.'\n\nLim, the senior pastor of the Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, had made frequent humanitarian visits to North Korea on behalf of his church.\n\nThere ahave been concerns that Lim's health has suffered while in captivity, sparking diplomatic efforts to seek his release.\n\nThe delegation that arrived in North Korea today was headed by Daniel Jean, who serves as Justin Trudeau's national security advisor.\n\nCanadian officials had not yet commented at the time of writing.\n\n'Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case,' said Cameron Ahmad, a spokesperson for Trudeau, yesterday.\n\nThe release comes amid heightened tensions between North Korea and the West after the US President Donald Trump reacted with fury to an intelligence report that suggested Pyongyang had the nuclear firepower to hit America.\n\nTrump warned North Korea's supreme leader Kim Jong-un any threats would be met 'with fire and fury and, frankly, power the likes of which the world has never seen before'.\n\nNorth Korea responded by saying on state media it is considering a strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam.\n\nPyongyang has been carrying out several missile tests in recent weeks and has tested nuclear devices five times, including two intercontinental ballistic middles (ICBM) in July, in what are perceived to be acts of aggression towards the West.\n\nIn response the UN approved further economic sanctions on North Korea on Saturday in an attempt to pressurise Kim Jong-un to give up his nuclear weapons.\n\nA senior Canadian official said their trip was solely linked to Lim's condition and was not related to the increasing global tensions with the state.", "time": "11:33:00"}

"http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/n-korea-frees-jailed-canadian-pastor", "body": "SEOUL * A Canadian pastor serving a life sentence with hard labour in North Korea was released yesterday on medical parole as a humanitarian gesture, the KCNA news agency said.\n\nMr Lim Hyeon Soo, 61, was freed on \"sick bail\", the agency announced after a Canadian government delegation, including National Security Adviser Daniel Jean, visited Pyongyang this week to discuss the case.\n\nA court ordered Mr Lim's release \"from the humanitarian viewpoint\", it said in a brief two-paragraph report.\n\nMr Lim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs. The South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation which the Canadian authorities strongly denied. Mr Lim's family told the media they had become increasingly worried about his welfare since the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, days after being freed by North Korea.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nAt the time of Mr Lim's arrest, members of the circle of ethnic Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States called him one of the most influential Christian missionaries in North Korea.\n\nAGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE", "time": "21:06:00"}

"http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/north-korea-canadian-detained-hyeon-soo-lim-1.4239356", "body": "North Korea nuclear threat renews debate on Canada's participation in U.S. missile defence\n\nA top Canadian security official has arrived in North Korea hoping to negotiate the release of an imprisoned Canadian pastor, CBC News has confirmed.\n\nThe reclusive regime's state-run media reported Monday that Daniel Jean, the national security and intelligence adviser to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, was in Pyongyang leading a delegation to discuss the case of Toronto Presbyterian minister Rev. Hyeon Soo Lim.\n\nA spokesperson for Trudeau would only confirm that a Canadian delegation is present in the internationally isolated capital.\n\n\"Obviously, Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada and we are continuing to engage on his case,\" said Cameron Ahmad in a statement.\n\n\"As this is an active case, we will not provide any further comment.\"\n\nSeparately, a senior government official confirmed to CBC News that Jean was leading the delegation as the prime minister's special envoy, and that while his focus is the release of Lim, he would also be free to \"discuss other issues of regional concern.\"\n\nThe delegation arrived on the same day U.S. President Donald Trump warned that North Korea would be met \"with fire, fury and frankly power the likes of which this world has never seen,\" if it does not stop threatening the United States.\n\nEarlier Tuesday, there were reports citing U.S. intelligence analysts that Kim Jong-un's regime has managed to produce a miniaturized nuclear warhead that can fit atop a ballistic missile.\n\nThe Canadian official said the timing of the visit was based on the condition of Lim, and not directly related to the increasing world tensions associated with North Korea's repeated missile tests and last weekend's imposition of further sanctions by the United Nations.\n\nThe 62-year-old reverend, who was sentenced to a life of hard labour in prison by the North Korean regime for crimes against the state, is reportedly in poor health.\n\nHe was arrested in 2015 and charged with harming the dignity of the supreme leadership and trying to use religion to destroy the North Korean system, among other things.\n\nAccording to media reports earlier this summer, Lim has problems with high blood pressure and complained about pains in the stomach in letters to friends.\n\nHis family urged Trudeau to personally take up his plight.\n\nTheir pleas came in the aftermath of the death of Otto Warmbier, the U.S. citizen who was held in captivity by North Korea and released only to die a few days later.", "time": "21:25:00"}

"https://guardian.ng/news/canadian-pastor-on-way-home-after-north-korea-release/", "body": "A Canadian pastor was on his way home Thursday after being released from a North Korean prison where he spent the last two years, according to his family and the prime minister.\n\nNorth Korea's official KCNA news agency announced Hyeon Soo Lim's release Wednesday, saying he was freed on \"sick bail.\"\n\nThis came after a Canadian government delegation led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean traveled to Pyongyang to discuss the 62-year-old's case.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his granddaughter for the first time,\" Lisa Pak, a spokeswoman for the family, said in a statement.\n\nShe said the family was \"relieved, grateful, excited, and anxious to see him home.\"\n\nPak also thanked Canadian officials who \"worked behind the scenes with North Korean authorities\" to secure his release, as well as Swedish diplomats who assisted them.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a statement that he was \"pleased and relieved\" to confirm Lim's release, adding that Lim would \"soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada.\"\n\nLim was arrested in 2015 for allegedly meddling in North Korean state affairs.\n\nThe South Korean-born pastor had been accused of subversive acts against Pyongyang, an allegation Canadian authorities strongly denied.\n\nLim's family became increasingly worried about his welfare after the death of American student Otto Warmbier in June, days after he had been released from a North Korean prison.\n\nThree US citizens remain in custody as tensions with Washington have sharpened. The North said Wednesday it was considering a missile strike near US bases in Guam.\n\nThat comment came hours after US President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with \"fire and fury\" over its missile program.\n\nLim last year told CNN he spent his days in prison digging holes at an orchard. \"I wasn't originally a laborer so the labor was hard at first,\" he said, his head shaven.\n\nPak said Lim has \"a long way to go in terms of... healing.\"\n\nTrudeau said Lim's \"health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention.\"\n\nAt the time of Lim's arrest, other members of the close-knit circle of ethnic Korean missionaries in Canada and the United States called him one of the most influential Christian missionaries operating in North Korea.\n\nHe had visited the country dozens of times, working with orphanages and nursing homes.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim Jong-Un.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\nPyongyang views foreign missionaries with deep suspicion, though it allows some to undertake humanitarian work.\n\nA number of Christian missionaries -- mostly ethnic Koreans who are US citizens -- have been arrested in the past, with some of them only allowed to return home after intervention by high-profile US political figures.", "time": "13:13:00"}

Pyongyang by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean\n\nA Canadian pastor imprisoned in North Korea for more than two years returned home Saturday days after being released, officials said.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, was arrested in January 2015 on charges of subversive activities against the North Korean regime, an accusation denied by Ottawa.\n\nAlthough sentenced to hard labor for life, he was granted \"sick bail\" following a visit to Pyongyang by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean.\n\n\"Today, we join Pastor Lim's family and congregation in celebrating his long-awaited return to Canada,\" the foreign affairs ministry said in a press statement.\n\n\"Canada has been actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels, and we will continue to support him and his family now that he has returned,\" it added.\n\nAccording to local media reports, Lim was flown to a military base in Trenton, some 170 kilometers (100 miles) east of Toronto.\n\nHis liberation came at a moment of high tensions between North Korea and the United States. Three Americans remain in the custody of the regime of Kim Jong-Un.\n\nPyongyang has threatened to launch missiles on the island Guam, a strategic US outpost in the Pacific some 3,300 kilometers (2000 miles) from North Korea.\n\nUS President Donald Trump for his part as promised to rain down \"fire and fury\" on Kim's regime.\n\nLim, who belongs to the Light Korean Presbyterian Church, was considered at the time of his arrest one of the most influential Christian missionaries in North Korea.\n\nHe had previously traveled extensively in the country to work in orphanages and hospitals.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.", "time": "00:57:00"}

"https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2017/08/11/freed-mississauga-pastor-will-be-back-in-church-for-sunday-service.html", "body": "On Sunday, Hyeon Soo Lim will return to the Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, which has wept, prayed and organized vigils for their pastor during the 2 \u00bd years he was detained in North Korea.\n\nOn Saturday, Hyeon Soo Lim will be reunited with his family in Toronto.\n\nAnd on Sunday, Lim will return to his church family -- the congregation of the Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, which has wept, prayed and organized vigils for their beloved senior pastor during the 2 \u00bd years he was detained in North Korea.\n\nThe reception for Lim is expected to pack the 2,000-seat facility where Lim used to preach weekly.\n\nLim's family is requesting privacy but their reaction to his freedom was \"relieved, grateful, excited and anxious to see him home,\" according to church spokesperson Richard Ha.\n\nLim has been able to phone church colleagues, who say he is doing well.\n\n\"He is in good spirits,\" said Jason Noh, an associate pastor at the Light Presbyterian Church.\n\nIn video footage taken Thursday by a Japanese television crew, Lim is on the tarmac of a U.S. military base in Fussa, Japan. His hair is shorn, he looks thinner but appears to be smiling and walking unaided with the Canadian delegation, led by Justin Trudeau's national security adviser, Daniel Jean.\n\nThe delegation reportedly flew to Japan from Pyongyang after North Korea's Central Court on Wednesday granted Lim \"sick bail\" on humanitarian grounds.\n\nThe delegation did not head straight home. The group jetted to Guam for a layover, according to sources. The return flight path is not known but Lim was expected to be in Toronto by Saturday.\n\nIn January 2015, Lim was detained by North Korean authorities while on a charitable mission to the country's northern region. Later that year, the pastor was convicted of attempting to subvert the authoritarian regime of Kim Jong Un and was sentenced to life in a labour camp.\n\nTrudeau confirmed Lim's freedom in a statement sent out by email at 1:13 a.m. Thursday. It read, in part: \"The Government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels. In particular, I want to thank Sweden, our protecting power in North Korea, for assisting us.\"\n\nThe Swedish Embassy in Pyongyang serves as Canada's protecting power in North Korea because Ottawa does not have an embassy there. Swedish ambassador Torkel Stiernl\u00f6f was able to meet with Lim a few times and, with North Korean approval, delivered family letters and prescription medication to him. Lim has high blood pressure that requires medicine.\n\nOn July 14, the North Korean state news agency reported that authorities had arranged a meeting between an unnamed Swedish embassy official and Lim \"on the basis of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations and in the humanitarian spirit.\"\n\nIt has been reported that Lim was in poor health and had lost a lot of weight.\n\nAccording to English-language reports citing the Korean Central News Agency article, Lim asked the Swedish diplomat in that July 14 meeting \"to convey his request to the Canadian government for making active efforts to settle his issue.\"\n\nOn Thursday, Global Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland wrote to thank her Swedish counterpart, Margot Wallstrom, on her Twitter account: \"Thank you for your tremendous support, @MargotWallstrom. Canadians are so grateful for #Sweden's long-standing, heartfelt friendship.\"\n\nIn Toronto, it's expected Lim's wife, Geum, their son James, his wife and 10-month-old daughter will be waiting for him. James, 34, and his family live in the United States. Geum Lim has spent a good deal of time in Seoul during her husband's detention and imprisonment.\n\nAll three Lims are natives of South Korea. The family immigrated to Canada, settling in Toronto, in 1986 when Lim had the opportunity to study at the University of Toronto's Knox College.", "time": "23:29:00"}

A plane carrying medical personnel, senior Canadian officials, and a letter to Kim Jong-un were sent to Pyongyang. The Canadian team arrived in North Korea Monday.\n\nLim's release follows the medical release of American prisoner Otto Warmbier, a University of Virginia student who was sent home in a coma. Warmbier died one week after returning home.\n\nThe North is still holding three U.S. citizens and at least six South Koreans.\n\nThe U.S. recently issued a ban restricting travel to North Korea for U.S. citizens, and that ban is expected to go into effect in early September. The North has said, however, that its doors remain open to any American citizens interested in visiting the country.\n\nTensions between North Korea and the U.S. are on the rise, as North Korea has threatened to take punitive action against the U.S. in response to new sanctions, as well as other perceived provocations. President Donald Trump warned Tuesday that North Korea's threats will be met with \"fire and fury and, frankly, power the likes of which this world has never seen before.\"", "time": "14:02:00"}

"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-canada-idUSKBN1AQ290", "body": "OTTAWA (Reuters) - A Canadian pastor freed from a North Korean prison on humanitarian grounds is healthy and not in critical condition, his family said on Thursday.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada, had been sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 after North Korea accused him of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\nOn Wednesday, North Korea's KCNA news agency said he was released on \"sick bail.\"\n\nLim is expected to return to Canada later on Thursday, a source familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.\n\nA spokeswoman for the family, Lisa Pak, said the latest update on Lim's well-being is that he is healthy and \"not in critical condition.\" The family is \"relieved, grateful, excited, anxious to see him home,\" Pak said.\n\nFootage from Japan's ANN television showed Lim walking on a tarmac next to Canada's national security adviser, Daniel Jean, at the Yokata Air Base on the outskirts of Tokyo. Lim also was seen shaking hands with various unidentified people.\n\nLim's release came amid heightened rhetoric between Washington and Pyongyang but there was no clear connection between the two.\n\nLim's case was taken up by a delegation led by Jean that had gone to North Korea earlier in the week. Sweden's embassy in Pyongyang, which represents several Western nations in the insular nation, also helped, according to a statement from Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.", "time": "18:50:00"}

"http://wdsm710.com/news/articles/2017/aug/13/canadian-church-welcomes-pastor-home-from-north-korean-prison/", "body": "TORONTO (Reuters) - The congregation of one of Canada's largest churches welcomed their former pastor home on Sunday, the day after his return from North Korea, where he had been imprisoned for more than 2 1/2 years.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, sat in the front row of a packed worship hall at Light Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, a Toronto suburb. He was accompanied by family members, including his 1-year-old granddaughter, who was born while he was in captivity.\n\nIt was his first public appearance since his return to Canada on Saturday. Lim and Canadian officials have yet to discuss the details of his ordeal in North Korea, the reason for his arrest or what prompted his release from a life sentence of hard labor on charges that he sought to overthrow the Pyongyang regime.\n\n\"Reverend Lim's release was a miracle, work of God,\" said the Korean church's founder, emeritus pastor Chai Hoon Park.\n\nPark said Lim told him late on Saturday that he thought he would die as a martyr in North Korea and only learned of his release 10 minutes before he was let go.\n\n\"'They told me to go get changed. Then I was turned over to the Canadian delegation,'\" Park quoted Lim as telling him.\n\nLim's release, which was announced on Wednesday, came amid heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang, although authorities have not said there is any connection between his return and efforts to defuse the standoff over North Korea's nuclear program.\n\nLim's son James said at a Saturday news conference that the pastor was in \"good health\" but noted that the family planned to arrange for extended medical attention, including checkups.\n\n\"He is doing very well, considering everything he has gone through,\" he said.\n\n(Reporting by Hyungwon Kang in Mississauga; Writing by Jim Finkle; Editing by Lisa Von Ahn)", "time": "16:51:00"}

suffer the same fate as American student Otto Warmbier.\n\nSouth Korea-born reverend Hyeon Soo Lim has been detained in the rogue state since 2015 following his arrest for his alleged involvement in subversive acts against Pyongyang.\n\nHe was charged for allegedly harming the dignity of the North Korean leadership, among others. North Korea also accused Hyeon of trying to overthrow the Kim regime using religion and was eventually sentenced to hard labour for life.\n\nHowever, Toronto rejected all the allegations against Hyeon, who served at one of the largest churches in Canada.\n\nA delegation led by Canada's national security adviser and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's intelligence adviser, Daniel Jean, is now reported to be negotiating with North Korean officials to secure the pastor's release.\n\n\"A Canadian government delegation is currently in Pyongyang, DPRK, to discuss Pastor Lim's case,\" AFP news agency cited Trudeau spokesman Cameron Ahmad as saying, referring to North Korea's official name.\n\nThis is reported to be the second time in about nine months that a top Canadian official has been sent to Pyongyang to secure the release of Hyeon, the last time being in December 2016.\n\n\"His health and wellbeing remain of utmost importance to the government and we are obviously continuing to engage on his case and, given that it is an active case, we cannot provide any further comment at this time,\" the spokesman added.\n\nThe 62-year-old pastor is reported to be in poor health now, suffering from high blood pressure and had earlier complained of stomach pain.\n\nAccording to local media reports, Hyeon's family has become very concerned over the pastor's well-being since the death of Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nNorth Korea released 22-year-old American student Warmbier, who had like Hyeon been detained for his alleged involvement in subversive acts, on 13 June on \"humanitarian grounds\". He was medically evacuated to the US on a military plane the following day after serving prison in North Korea for 17 months. But his family said he arrived in a state of coma, and eventually died on 19 June.\n\nHyeon had visited the isolated nation dozens of times to help set up and work with orphanages and nursing homes. At the time of his arrest, he was called by his kith and kin as one of the most influential Christian missionaries operating in North Korea.\n\nThe pastor was reportedly involved in projects linked to some associates of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un's purged uncle, Jang Song Thaek, who was executed in 2013 for treason.\n\nIn an interview with CNN last year, the pastor said he usually spends eight hours a day digging holes in the prison where he has apparently not seen any other inmates.", "time": "11:52:00"}

Premature Ejaculation, Weak Erection, Watery Sperm, Other Sexual Dysfunctions And Last More Than 30 Minutes During Sex.\n\nA Canadian pastor who had been sentenced to hard labor for life in North Korea was released on humanitarian grounds on Wednesday, the North's official media said.\n\nThe Rev. Lim Hyeon-soo, a South Korea-born pastor of the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Toronto, received his penalty in December 2015, when North Korea's Supreme Court convicted him of carrying out \"subversive plots\" and committing \"activities against\" the country, like harming the dignity of the supreme leadership of Kim Jong-un.\n\nMr. Lim was released on Wednesday, when the same court decided to free him on sick bail, the North's official Korean Central News Agency said. The agency's one-sentence dispatch gave no further detail.\n\nThe release of Mr. Lim came two months after an American college student, Otto F. Warmbier, died shortly after he was freed from North Korea while in a coma. Mr. Warmbier, 22, was serving a sentence of 15 years of hard labor for trying to steal a political poster from a Pyongyang hotel.\n\nHis death angered many Americans and eventually convinced the State Department to ban Americans from visiting North Korea.\n\nMr. Lim, who had visited North Korea more than 100 times on what his church called humanitarian missions, lost contact with his congregation after entering the country in early 2015. A tearful Mr. Lim later appeared in a government-arranged news conference in Pyongyang and confessed to plotting to overthrow the North Korean leadership by undermining the \"worship\" of Kim Jong-un.\n\nHis church had supported a nursing home, a nursery and an orphanage in North Korea since it began a mission there in 1996, when the country was in the grip of a famine that killed thousands of people.\n\nMr. Lim said during his news conference that the bags of food he had donated across North Korea had carried the sign of the cross and phrases from the Bible. North Korean prosecutors also accused him of helping \"lure and abduct\" North Korean citizens, calling them defectors.\n\nNorth Korea, which zealously tries to shield its citizens from outside influences, has detained several foreign missionaries in recent years, calling them spies or agents of subversive ideas.\n\nKenneth Bae, a Korean-American missionary sentenced to 15 years of hard labor for trying to establish a secret proselytizing network, was freed in 2014, after the United States government sent its director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., to North Korea.\n\nDuring his detention or trial, Mr. Lim's family members were not allowed to visit him, and appealed repeatedly to North Korea to free him.", "time": "14:12:00"}

"http://www.rcinet.ca/en/2017/08/10/trudeau-confirms-release-of-ailing-canadian-pastor-imprisoned-in-north-korea/", "body": "Prime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed Thursday the release of Canadian pastor Hyeon Soo Lim from a North Korean hard labour camp and thanked Sweden for its role in helping to secure his freedom.\n\nNorth Korea's official news agency had announced Wednesday that the 62-year-old pastor and humanitarian worker who suffers from high blood pressure was released for health reasons.\n\nLim, who had visited North Korea dozens of times since 1997, was serving a life sentence of hard labour after he was arrested and convicted in 2015 of \"crimes against the state.\"\n\n\"Today, I am pleased and relieved to confirm that Pastor Lim has been released from jail in North Korea and that he will soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada,\" Trudeau said in a statement released early Thursday morning.\n\n\"The Government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels. In particular, I want to thank Sweden, our protecting power in North Korea, for assisting us.\"\n\nThe Lim family spokesperson Lisa Pak also said they are grateful to the Canadian government and the Swedish embassy in North Korea for working behind the scenes to secure the pastor's freedom.\n\nCanadian Pastor Lim released from jail in North Korea. Glad Sweden, as Canada's protecting power in NK, could assist https://t.co/I6O10looX3\n\n-- Margot Wallstr\u00f6m (@margotwallstrom) August 10, 2017\n\nCanada has no diplomatic representation in Pyongyang and Sweden acts as its \"protecting power\" when it comes to consular issues affecting Canadians in North Korea.\n\nOfficials in the Prime Minister's Office did not confirm any further details about Lim's release or when exactly he is expected to be back on Canadian soil.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the Government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention,\" Trudeau said.\n\n\"Operational security considerations prevent us from discussing the matter further,\" he added, asking the media to respect the family's privacy.\n\nLim's release came after Trudeau dispatched Daniel Jean, his national security and intelligence adviser, to the North Korean capital to discuss the pastor's case.\n\nJean's mission to Pyongyang was an exceptional step given the state of diplomatic relations between Canada and North Korea, and the escalating tensions between the North and the United States.\n\nPyongyang's already strained relations with Washington spiked to new levels of hostility after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened North Korea that it \"will be met with fire and fury\" if it threatens the U.S.\n\nThe North responded on Wednesday with its own threats, saying that it had been drawing up plans for a missile strike against the Pacific island of Guam, which is home to U.S. military bases, strategic bombers and about 163,000 people.\n\nCanada recognized the Democratic People's Republic of Korea - North Korea's official name - in 2000. The two countries established diplomatic relations in 2001.\n\nHowever, following North Korea's aggressive actions in 2010, including the sinking of a South Korean warship in a disputed area, led Canada to impose tight restrictions on the relationship.\n\nOttawa announced the adoption of a Controlled Engagement Policy toward North Korea, which remains in place today.\n\nAccording to Global Affairs Canada, under this policy, Ottawa's official contacts with Pyongyang are limited to subjects concerning only regional security concerns, the human rights and humanitarian situation in North Korea, inter-Korean relations, and consular issues.\n\n\"All government-to-government cooperation and communication on topics not covered under the Controlled Engagement Policy has been suspended,\" Global Affairs says on its website.\n\nIn addition, in August 2011, Canada imposed economic sanctions against North Korea under the Special Economic Measures Act (SEMA). Under the SEMA sanctions, Canadian individuals and companies are banned from trading with North Korea and making new investments there, as well as providing financial services to North Korea and North Korean nationals.\n\nThe provision of humanitarian goods is exempted from the SEMA sanctions that were in addition to sanctions imposed by the UN Security Council and implemented in Canadian law.", "time": "16:27:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction", "label": {"eng": "North Korea and weapons of mass destruction"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "380344"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Bae", "label": {"eng": "Kenneth Bae"}, "score": 3, "type": "person", "id": "697409"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyeon_Soo_Lim", "label": {"eng": "Hyeon Soo Lim"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288147"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Warmbier", "label": {"eng": "Otto Warmbier"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1288189"}], "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/north-koreas-release-of-toronto-pastor-regarded-as-political-move/article35938520/", "body": "Hyeon Soo Lim emerged on Thursday at a U.S. Air Force base in Japan appearing calm and healthy, a development seen as a sign that North Korea released the Canadian pastor as an offering of goodwill to Western countries at a time when Pyongyang is at the epicentre of global political tensions.\n\nThe sight of Mr. Lim walking around with apparent ease, and his family's report that he is believed to be healthy, suggest his release was motivated by political, rather than humanitarian, reasons. It is not known exactly when Mr. Lim, who is in his early 60s, will land back in Canada.\n\nHe was freed this week on \"sick bail\" from a North Korean labour camp after a Canadian delegation, led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security adviser Daniel Jean, visited the isolated country to discuss the pastor's case.\n\nThe decision comes as Washington and Pyongang trade increasing threats about the possibility of nuclear action, with U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday warning that his previous remarks about North Korea being \"met with fire and fury like the world has never seen\" may not have been \"tough enough.\" Meanwhile, North Korea vowed to ignite an \"enveloping fire\" of test missiles, designed to land 30 to 40 kilometres offshore of the U.S. territory of Guam.\n\nNorth Korea's handling of American prisoner Otto Warmbier, who was released on June 13 but died six days later, had sparked intense criticism in the United States and may have fuelled the political appetite for confronting North Korea over its long-range nuclear missile program.\n\nUnder those circumstances, there was thinking that Pyongyang might be eager to release a prisoner in grave health. But Mr. Lim, who is said to have high blood pressure and endured weight loss while in custody, appeared to be in good health, based on the news footage of him in Japan on Thursday.\n\nBut the international political tensions over North Korea's nuclear program might have made the regime more willing to release Mr. Lim now, some North Korea observers believe. Under so much pressure from the United States, it might want to appear to be acting reasonably with other countries.\n\n\"I think it is possible that North Korea wanted to make some kind of de-icing gesture with Western countries,\" said Peter Lee, the chief executive of the U.S. branch of the North Korea Strategy Centre.\n\nIt's also not the first time that North Korea has released a prisoner for non-health reasons - usually after a series of secret negotiations and on condition that a high-level delegation is dispatched. James Clapper, the former U.S. director of national intelligence, went to Pyongyang to secure the release of two prisoners: Matthew Miller and Kenneth Bae. Former U.S. presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, both out of office, also conducted such missions. Such delegations help the regime keep face, Mr. Lee said.\n\nTypically, such envoys carry a letter from the national leader - Mr. Clapper, for example, carried a letter from then-president Barack Obama that described the release of two prisoners as a \"positive gesture.\"\n\nBrock University professor Charles Burton, who writes about China and North Korea, said it would be typical for Mr. Trudeau to send such a letter with his envoy. \"I think that would have been critical to the success of the whole operation.\"\n\nMr. Trudeau's office would not confirm whether the Prime Minister sent a letter or offered any concession in exchange for Mr. Lim's release.\n\nMr. Lim, who served in one of the largest churches in Canada and travelled to North Korea regularly on humanitarian missions, was sentenced by the country's Supreme Court in December, 2015, to a lifetime of hard labour after being accused of attempting to overthrow the regime.\n\nPaul Evans, a professor at the University of British Columbia's Institute of Asian Research, also cited the Warmbier case as a potential factor in Mr. Lim's release.\n\nBut he also said Pyongang could be attempting to re-engage with Canada, and sees an opportunity with the Trudeau government after harsh treatment by the previous Conservative government.\n\n\"My sense is that the North Koreans consistently have wanted representation and interaction with Canadian government officials. It is us who have closed the door to the North Koreans,\" Prof. Evans said.\n\nHe also said the country could be fascinated by Mr. Trudeau's ability to manage his relationship with Mr. Trump, and is attempting to expand its diplomatic scope with Washington.\n\n\"Some well-informed people are saying that in the midst of bombast from North Korea, that there are signs of a desire for discussions with the outside,\" Prof. Evans said, adding that it's \"really hard to tell.\"\n\n\"If they did want to do that, having Daniel Jean come could have been very useful to them. They would have seen it as exponentially valuable to them.\"\n\nLisa Pak, a spokeswoman for the Lim family who grew up with the pastor's son, James, said she believes Canada sent a strong diplomatic message to North Korea by sending Mr. Jean as the Prime Minister's special envoy.\n\n\"I really applaud Canada's approach this time,\" she said. \"It was such a foil against all the other negative rhetoric that's been going back and forth.\"\n\nMs. Pak said Mr. Lim's family is \"relieved, grateful, excited, anxious to see him home,\" where he will meet his granddaughter for the first time. The family also thanked Mr. Trudeau, Canadian officials and the Swedish embassy in Pyongyang, which helps Canada with diplomatic matters in a country where Canada does not have a diplomatic presence.\n\n\"There is a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing, therefore, in the meantime we ask the media for privacy as he reconnects with his loved ones and receives medical attention,\" the family said in a statement. \"Finally, we want to thank the global community for the continued prayers and support and we also ask that the world does not forget the people of North Korea.\"\n\nMr. Trudeau on Thursday officially confirmed Mr. Lim's release, almost a day after North Korean media first reported that the pastor had been freed. It is unclear what transpired during that time and the PMO has said it wouldn't comment on an active case.\n\nJoseph Caron, Canada's ambassador to China between 2001 and 2005, said the fact that the North Koreans released information about Mr. Lim before Canada suggests they were \"doing this, of course, for their own purposes.\"\n\n\"On the Canadian side - it isn't over until it's over. You're dealing with a regime that is totally unpredictable and quite possibly the ... communications decision was, we don't move until everything is in order, and maybe he's even out of the airspace,\" he said.\n\nMr. Trudeau said little about what led to Mr. Lim's release - \"operational security considerations prevent us from discussing the matter further\" - but noted the role of Mr. Jean and Sweden in securing Mr. Lim's release.", "time": "03:03:00"}

"type": "wiki", "id": "1288147"}], "url": "http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/pastor-freed-north-korea-1.4241461", "body": "How Canada secured the release of pastor imprisoned in North Korea\n\nAn ailing Canadian pastor is expected to be reunited with his loved ones today after being held for more than two years in North Korea, but he still has \"a long way to go\" toward regaining his health, according to his family.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim is due to return to Canada on Thursday, though the details of his arrival have not been released. His family said in a statement they are \"relieved\" the 62-year-old pastor is coming home, but asked for privacy as he reconnects with his loved ones and receives medical attention.\n\nLim's prison sentence was suddenly cut short on Wednesday because of what Pyongyang called \"humanitarian\" grounds. He is known to need medication to manage high blood pressure and was reportedly in poor health during his time in North Korea.\n\nLim was sentenced to hard labour for life in December 2015 for what North Korea said was an attempt to overthrow the regime. Ottawa sent a delegation earlier this week to negotiate his release.\n\nHis family thanked Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and other officials, including Sweden's ambassador to North Korea, for their efforts. Canada does not have diplomatic offices in Pyongyang and relies on Sweden to handle consular issues.\n\nLim will meet his granddaughter for the first time when he returns home, according to a statement from his family. His wife and son live in the Toronto area, and he is attached to the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ont., one of the largest churches in Canada.\n\nThe church has said he visited North Korea more than 100 times since 1997 and helped set up an orphanage and nursing home. Family and friends say he was visiting those projects at the time of his arrest in February 2015.", "time": "12:37:00"}

"http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ani/north-korea-frees-imprisoned-canadian-pastor-after-years-in-detention-117081000066_1.html", "body": "North Korea has released a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence in the country after two and a half years in detention.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, convicted of crimes against the state in December 2015, was \"released on sick bail\" Wednesday by the country's top court for \"humanitarian\" reasons, CNN quoted state-run news agency KCNA as saying.\n\nLim's son, James Lim, was informed over the weekend that a letter to Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un was dispatched in a plane carrying senior Canadian officials and a medical doctor, to Pyongyang at the last minute, said a family spokeswoman, Lisa Pak.\n\nPak said that the pastor's health had worsened while in North Korean custody and he had also experienced dramatic weight loss.\n\nAccording to the reports, Lim's family had stepped up calls for his release since the death of University of Virginia student Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nA travel ban preventing nearly all the U.S. citizens from visiting North Korea was announced by the U.S. State Department that will take effect next month since Warmbier's death with the exception for journalists and humanitarian workers.\n\nLim had complained of stomach pain and high blood pressure in his letters to family, friends and members of his church in Mississauga, Ontario.\n\nLim's family was able to send him letters and blood pressure medication via the Swedish embassy in Pyongyang as they were not allowed to see him during his imprisonment.\n\nSwedish embassy in Pyongyang often serves as an intermediary for prisoners from nations with no formal diplomatic ties to North Korea.\n\nHe was detained in February 2015 while on a humanitarian mission in Rajin, North Korea.\n\nLim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997 for his humanitarian efforts in the country.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business updated at 14:30 KST to reflect a statement by a Canadian government spokesperson.\n\nA delegation of the Canadian Government arrived in Pyongyang on Tuesday, according to a report published by the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) on the same day.\n\nThe brief report only announces the arrival of the delegation in the country and does not include any details on the purpose of the visit by Canadian representatives.\n\n\"Daniel Jean, national security advisor to the prime minister of Canada who is special envoy of the Canadian prime minister, and his party arrived here Tuesday,\" the article reads.\n\nNo further details were included by North Korea's primary state media outlet, but a press officer for Justin Trudeau, Canada's Prime Minister, confirmed to Reuters that the group was visiting to discuss the case of Pastor Hyeon Soo Lim, a Canadian currently imprisoned in North Korea.\n\n\"A Canadian government delegation is currently in Pyongyang to discuss Pastor Lim's case,\" press secretary Cameron Ahmad said.\n\n\"His health and wellbeing remain of utmost importance to the government and we are obviously continuing to engage on his case and, given that it is an active case, we cannot provide any further comment at this time.\"\n\nLim went missing during a trip to North Korea in January 2015 after traveling to the country in order to continue working on humanitarian projects previously established with the blessing of the North Korean government.\n\nIn March 2015 it emerged that Lim had been arrested and he was subsequently sentenced to a life sentence of hard labor in December of the same year for numerous charges, including what DPRK authorities claimed was an attempt to overthrow the government.\n\nLim was interviewed by CNN in January 2016 and revealed that he has been required to perform hard labor alone in a prison camp.\n\nIn December of 2016, another Canadian delegation visited Pyongyang to discuss Lim's case with North Korean authorities. Lim's family subsequently confirmed that the delegation was given consular access to Lim during the trip.\n\nLim's family has urged for the release of the Pastor throughout his detention and a spokesperson for the family told NK News on Tuesday that they were hopeful the current visit is related to Lim.\n\n\"There may be other reasons too for the visit. We are hoping that Reverend Lim's well-being and release are topics that are discussed,\" Lisa Pak, a spokesperson for the Light Presbyterian Korean Church in Toronto, told NK News.\n\nNorth Korea has previously criticized the government of Canada for expressing concern regarding Lim's case following his sentencing.\n\nEdited by Oliver Hotham\n\nFeatured Image: by Comrade Anatolii on 2013-04-26 08:13:16\n\nUpdate: This article was updated at 14:30 KST to reflect a statement by a Canadian government spokesperson. "Canadian officials on Wednesday were silent on the condition of Hyeon Soo Lim, the pastor who was released by North Korea after a Canadian delegation asked for his release this week.\n\nNorth Korea said Lim was released because of his poor health, which led to worries in Canada and among Lim's family that he might suffer the fate of Otto Warmbier, the U.S. student who was held captive and then released only to die soon after he returned to the U.S.\n\nOfficials in Canada were not giving any indications about Lim's health, according to the Toronto Globe and Mail.\n\n\"His health and well being remain of utmost importance to the government and we are obviously continuing to engage on his case and, given that it is an active case, we cannot provide any further comment at this time,\" a Trudeau spokesman said yesterday, according to Reuters.\n\nStill, Canadian officials were clearly happy with the news of his release.\n\n\"Pleased to hear reports that Pastor Lim has been released by North Korea,\" Andrew Scheer, leader of Canada's conservative opposition party, tweeted Wednesday. \"Thankful for Canadian negotiators and praying he's in good health.\"\n\nWarmbier's release and subsequent death was one of the many flashpoints between the U.S. and North Korea, which is still holding three U.S. citizens. The Trump White House made it clear it believed Warmbier was treated poorly while he was being held.\n\nAfter the United Nations imposed new sanctions against North Korea, news broke that the rogue regime could have the capacity to deliver a nuclear warhead to the United States on a missile, which prompted a war of words between North Korea and the United States.\n\nPresident Trump warned North Korea not to make \"any more threats\" against the United States. \"They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen,\" Trump said Tuesday.\n\nNorth Korean military officials retorted that they are \"carefully examining\" a preemptive strike against Guam, a U.S. territory in the Pacific with major military installations. But Secretary of State Rex Tillerson downplayed the threat during a flight to the island.\n\n\"Americans should sleep well at night,\" Tillerson told reporters. \"I never considered re-routing the trip back, and I do not believe that there is any imminent threat, in my own view.\"\n\nLim, a Korean-Canadian pastor, was arrested on charges of \"\"subversive plots\" against Kim Jong Un's dictatorship in 2015, during one of more than 100 trips to the country, according to South Korean media. He is the second western prisoner released from North Korea in two months.\n\nThe pastor's release, following the arrival of a Canadian envoy, might auger for the direct negotiations between the United States and North Korea that Russia and China have endorsed. But Tillerson maintained that any talks cannot take place until North Korea recognizes the imperative that they will have to surrender their nuclear weapons program.\n\n\"We don't think having a dialogue where the North Koreans come to the table assuming they're going to maintain their nuclear weapons is productive,\" Secretary of State Rex Tillerson told reporters last week.", "time": "18:54:00"}

conference at his church in the Toronto suburb of Mississauga, family spokeswoman Lisa Pak said in a statement. Pak said it was not clear whether Pastor Lim, 62, would be at the press conference, but said he would attend church services on Sunday.\n\nLim, a leader of one of Canada's largest churches, had been sentenced to hard labor for life in December 2015 on charges of attempting to overthrow the North Korean regime.\n\nNorth Korea's KCNA news agency said on Wednesday that he was released on humanitarian grounds, though his family later said he was not in critical condition.\n\nFootage from Japan's ANN television showed Lim walking on a tarmac next to Canada's national security adviser, Daniel Jean, at the Yokota Air Base on the outskirts of Tokyo, in a stop en route to his home.\n\nLim's return to Canada comes amid heightened tensions between Washington and Pyongyang, though there authorities have not said there is any connection.", "time": "16:32:00"}

military base in Trenton, some 170 kilometers (100 miles) east of Toronto.\n\nHis liberation came at a moment of high tensions between North Korea and the United States. Three Americans remain in the custody of the regime of Kim Jong-Un.\n\nPyongyang has threatened to launch missiles on the island Guam, a strategic US outpost in the Pacific some 3,300 kilometers (2000 miles) from North Korea.\n\nUS President Donald Trump for his part as promised to rain down \"fire and fury\" on Kim's regime.\n\nLim, who belongs to the Light Korean Presbyterian Church, was considered at the time of his arrest one of the most influential Christian missionaries in North Korea.\n\nHe had previously traveled extensively in the country to work in orphanages and hospitals.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "time": "04:07:00"}

"http://www.sify.com/news/north-korea-frees-imprisoned-canadian-pastor-after-years-in-detention-news-international-rikcLuhbcjfcj.html", "body": "[North Korea], Aug 10 (ANI): North Korea has released a Canadian pastor serving a life sentence in the country after two and a half years in detention.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, convicted of crimes against the state in December 2015, was \"released on sick bail\" Wednesday by the country's top court for \"humanitarian\" reasons, CNN quoted state-run news agency KCNA as saying.\n\nLim's son, James Lim, was informed over the weekend that a letter to Supreme Leader Kim Jong Un was dispatched in a plane carrying senior Canadian officials and a medical doctor, to Pyongyang at the last minute, said a family spokeswoman, Lisa Pak.\n\nPak said that the pastor's health had worsened while in North Korean custody and he had also experienced dramatic weight loss.\n\nAccording to the reports, Lim's family had stepped up calls for his release since the death of University of Virginia student Otto Warmbier in June.\n\nA travel ban preventing nearly all the U.S. citizens from visiting North Korea was announced by the U.S. State Department that will take effect next month since Warmbier's death with the exception for journalists and humanitarian workers.\n\nLim had complained of stomach pain and high blood pressure in his letters to family, friends and members of his church in Mississauga, Ontario.\n\nLim's family was able to send him letters and blood pressure medication via the Swedish embassy in Pyongyang as they were not allowed to see him during his imprisonment.\n\nSwedish embassy in Pyongyang often serves as an intermediary for prisoners from nations with no formal diplomatic ties to North Korea.\n\nHe was detained in February 2015 while on a humanitarian mission in Rajin, North Korea.\n\nLim has made more than 100 trips to North Korea since 1997 for his humanitarian efforts in the country. (ANI)\n\nSEARCH", "time": "21:34:00"}

in early 2015, Lim was sentenced to a life of hard labour on December 16, 2015 for 'harming the dignity of the supreme leader,' 'trying to use religion to destroy North Korea' and 'assisting North Koreans escape.'\n\nNow in his 60s, Lim's health is worsening according to a Canadian delegation who visited him last year and letters to his friends say he is suffering from high blood pressure and stomach pains.\n\nConfirming the presence of the diplomatic negotiation, Trudeau's spokesman Cameron Ahmad, said: 'Obviously, Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada as we continue to engage on this case.'\n\nIt comes at a high of heightened tensions between North Korea and the West after US President Donald Trump reacted with fury to an intelligence report that suggested Pyongyang had the nuclear firepower to hit America.\n\nTrump warned North Korea's supreme leader Kim Jong-un any threats would be met 'with fire and fury and, frankly, power the likes of which the world has never seen before'.\n\nNorth Korea responded by saying on state media it is considering a strike on the US Pacific territory of Guam.\n\nPyongyang has been carrying out several missile tests in recent weeks and has tested nuclear devices five times, including two intercontinental ballistic middles (ICBM) in July, in what are perceived to be acts of aggression towards the West.\n\nIn response the UN approved further economic sanctions on North Korea on Saturday in an attempt to pressurise Kim Jong-un to give up his nuclear weapons.\n\nA senior Canadian official said their trip was solely linked to Lim's condition and was not related to the increasing global tensions with the state.", "time": "06:30:00"}

"http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/922419/canadian-pastor-returns-home-after-north-korea-ordeal", "body": "North Korea's border county of Kaepoong is seen from a South Korean observation post in Paju near the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) dividing two Koreas on August 11, 2017.\n\nA Canadian pastor imprisoned in North Korea for more than two years returned home Saturday days after being released, officials said.\n\nHyeon Soo Lim, 62, was arrested in January 2015 on charges of subversive activities against the North Korean regime, an accusation denied by Ottawa.\n\nAlthough sentenced to hard labor for life, he was granted \"sick bail\" following a visit to Pyongyang by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's national security advisor Daniel Jean.\n\n\"Today, we join Pastor Lim's family and congregation in celebrating his long-awaited return to Canada,\" the foreign affairs ministry said in a press statement.\n\n\"Canada has been actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels, and we will continue to support him and his family now that he has returned,\" it added.\n\nAccording to local media reports, Lim was flown to a military base in Trenton, some 170 kilometers (100 miles) east of Toronto.\n\nHis liberation came at a moment of high tensions between North Korea and the United States. Three Americans remain in the custody of the regime of Kim Jong-Un.\n\nPyongyang has threatened to launch missiles on the island Guam, a strategic US outpost in the Pacific some 3,300 kilometers (2000 miles) from North Korea.\n\nUS President Donald Trump for his part as promised to rain down \"fire and fury\" on Kim's regime.\n\nLim, who belongs to the Light Korean Presbyterian Church, was considered at the time of his arrest one of the most influential Christian missionaries in North Korea.\n\nHe had previously traveled extensively in the country to work in orphanages and hospitals.\n\nBut some projects he worked on, including a noodle plant and flour mills, were linked to associates of Jang Song-Thaek, the purged uncle of leader Kim.\n\nJang was arrested and executed for treason in December 2013.", "time": "07:42:00"}

government and set up a \"religious state\".\n\nMr Lim's family said he had travelled to Pyongyang in January 2015 to build a nursing home, nursery and orphanage.\n\nHis church confirmed he had visited the country more than 100 times since 1997.\n\nBecause religious activity is banned in North Korea, the authorities periodically detain foreigners for religious or missionary activity, and similar cases have seen staged public confessions from prisoners.\n\nIn an interview with CNN in January 2016, Mr Lim described his hard labour sentence. "http://aa.com.tr/en/americas/pastor-freed-from-north-korea-expected-back-in-canada-/881809", "body": "A Toronto-area pastor who has been released from a North Korean prison while serving a life sentence for alleged crimes against the state is expected to arrive Thursday in Canada after more than two years in detention.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau expressed relief that pastor Hyeon Soo Lim of the Light Korean Presbyterian Church in Mississauga, Ontario, had been freed.\n\n\"Today, I am pleased and relieved to confirm that Pastor Lim has been released from jail in North Korea and that he will soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada,\" Trudeau said.\n\n\"The Government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels.\"\n\nCanada does not have an embassy in North Korea, and Trudeau thanked Sweden for playing the role of \"protecting power,\" in which a country that has diplomatic relations acts on behalf of another country.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of the utmost importance to the Government of Canada, and we are working to ensure he receives any required medical attention,\" Trudeau said in the statement on his website. \"Operational security considerations prevent us from discussing the matter further. I ask that the family's wish for privacy be respected.\"\n\nBut the family released a statement Thursday saying they are \"grateful to all parties involved\" and \"there is a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing\".\n\nNews of Lim's release came a day after a six-member Canadian government delegation arrived in North Korea to try to gain his freedom.\n\nHe had been charged with trying to overthrow the regime but had visited North Korea 100 times since 1997 and was instrumental in setting up an orphanage, nursery and nursing home there.\n\nNorth Korean officials said Lim's health was not good and he was released on humanitarian grounds.", "time": "07:02:00"}

"body": "'Guam is American soil': Politicians try to cut tension after North Korea's threat to attack\n\nAppearing thinner but in good spirits, Rev. Hyeon Soo Lim arrived by military jet at a U.S. airbase in Japan early today.\n\nThe pastor, who was released after more than two years in prison in North Korea, is seen in footage broadcast by Japan's TV Asahi. "label": {"eng": "NK News"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1314414"}], "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/pastor-released-from-north-korea-believed-in-good-health-family-says/article35938520/", "body": "Toronto pastor Hyeon Soo Lim is believed to be healthy and \"not in critical condition,\" a family spokeswoman said Thursday, as the former North Korean detainee makes his way back to Canada.\n\nIt is not known when or where Mr. Lim is expected to land following his release Wednesday from a North Korean labour camp. But family spokeswoman Lisa Pak said Mr. Lim, who suffers from high blood pressure and is believed to have lost a significant amount of weight, is expected to arrive in Canada in relatively stable health.\n\n\"He's healthy and not in critical condition,\" Ms. Pak told the Globe on Thursday, adding that there is a \"need to have more clear [medical] examinations\" upon Mr. Lim's return.\n\nNK News, a website that covers North Korea, reported on Thursday that a rare morning flight had departed Pyongyang's Sunan International Airport for the air base in Yokota, Japan, leading to speculation that Mr. Lim was aboard. CBC News released video of what it described as Mr. Lim, his head shaved bald, arriving on the tarmac in Japan. The Prime Minister's Office had no comment, citing operational security.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau on Thursday officially confirmed Mr. Lim's release, almost 24 hours after North Korea media first reported that the pastor had been freed on \"sick bail.\" It is unclear what transpired during that time, and the PMO has said it wouldn't comment on an active case.\n\nMr. Lim's release from prison came after a Canadian delegation, led by Mr. Trudeau's national security adviser Daniel Jean, arrived in North Korea to discuss the pastor's case. Mr. Trudeau also cited the role of Sweden, which has an embassy in Pyongyang, in helping to secure Mr. Lim's release.\n\n\"I am pleased and relieved to confirm that Pastor Lim has been released from jail in North Korea and that he will soon be reunited with his family and friends in Canada,\" Mr. Trudeau said in an early morning statement.\n\nMr. Trudeau said little about what led to Mr. Lim's release - \"operational security considerations prevent us from discussing the matter further\" - but noted the role of Mr. Jean and Sweden, which aids Canada on diplomatic matters in the rogue nation. The Canadian representatives arrived in Pyongyang in a government plane, according to a source with knowledge of the situation who spoke on condition of anonymity because of its sensitivity.\n\n\"The government of Canada was actively engaged on Mr. Lim's case at all levels,\" Mr. Trudeau said.\n\n\"Pastor Lim's health and well-being remain of utmost importance to the government of Canada, and we are working to ensure that he receives any required medical attention.\"\n\nMr. Lim's release comes at a time when Pyongyang is at the centre of high-pitched international tension over its nuclear-missile program that has dominated attention from Washington to Beijing. On Thursday, North Korea said it was completing plans to fire four intermediate-range missiles over Japan to land near the U.S. Pacific island territory of Guam, in an unusually detailed threat that further heightened tensions with the United States.\n\nMr. Lim's family is \"relieved, grateful, excited, anxious to see him home,\" Ms. Pak said in a statement Thursday, which also thanked Canadian and Swedish officials.\n\n\"We are relieved to hear that Reverend Lim is on his way home to finally reunite with his family and meet his granddaughter for the first time,\" the statement said.\n\n\"There is a long way to go in terms of Reverend Lim's healing, therefore, in the meantime we ask the media for privacy as he reconnects with his loved ones and receives medical attention. Finally, we want to thank the global community for the continued prayers and support and we also ask that the world does not forget the people of North Korea.\"\n\nIt's unclear whether the international tensions swirling around North Korea had any effect on the case of Mr. Lim, about whom family and friends were growing increasingly worried. But many experts have drawn comparisons to the case of Otto Warmbier, an American university student who fell into a coma while imprisoned in North Korea. Mr. Warmbier was released June 13, but died six days later in the United States.\n\nIt's possible that Mr. Lim's release might be North Korea's way of sending a goodwill message at a time of high tension, to try to portray itself as a reasonable country that can negotiate, said Steven Denney, a doctoral fellow at the Munk School of Global Affairs' Asian Institute.\n\n\"I think that North Korea understood that it was on thinner ice than usual,\" he said, adding that it's possible the regime is being more cautious with Mr. Lim's health problems.", "time": "18:50:00"}
